It called for enhanced transparency through ex-ante and ex-post social impact assessments of reforms, greater involvement of social partners and civil society in the European Semester process, and the use of the EU budget to support social initiatives and worker mobility. The Parliament highlighted gaps in addressing automatic stabilizers and the social consequences of macroeconomic interdependence, urging the December 2013 European Council to advance a social pillar within the EMU through the Community method. Additionally, it emphasized leveraging social entrepreneurship and innovation to create jobs, particularly in green and white economies, while ensuring democratic governance and civil dialogue in economic policymaking.

title: Motions for resolutions - Youth guarantee: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on a Youth Guarantee
background: Persistent high EU youth unemployment (23.4%, 5.68 million in 2012), exacerbated by economic crisis impacts, regional disparities, and projected long-term social costs, prompted the European Commission’s 2012 Youth Guarantee proposal. Informed by Eurofound research on Finland and Sweden, the Parliament will discuss structural measures to improve youth labor market integration and educational-to-employment transitions.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the Youth Guarantee issue for failing to address austerity policies exacerbating youth mental health crises, directly contradicting EFD's stance that economic rigidity fuels societal instability.  
EFD opposes the education alignment framework as structurally inadequate, noting it overlooks critical reforms to vocational training systems needed to resolve skills mismatches highlighted in Paška's debate intervention.  
EFD absolutely challenges with the issue’s reliance on EU funding mechanisms, arguing that allocating 25% of Structural Funds to ESF perpetuates fiscal centralization opposed by EFD principles.  
EFD condemns the issue’s silence on reversing austerity measures, which Salavrakos identifies as creating a “scientific proletariat” through systemic deprivation of youth opportunities.  
EFD disputes the cooperation model with EU institutions, asserting it entrenches top-down policies incompatible with national sovereignty in education and labor reforms.

SD totally approves the Youth Guarantee’s alignment with Europe 2020 goals, perfectly advancing S&D’s commitment to combatting youth unemployment through binding quality frameworks for education and fair working conditions.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for EU funding via Structural Funds, emphasizing Austria’s model of sustained investment as a blueprint for member states to replicate through ESF allocations.  
SD fully supports extending guarantees to recent graduates under 30, as outlined in the issue, to address Spain’s 56.6% youth unemployment and prevent generational exclusion from labor markets.  
SD endorses the urgency of implementing pilot projects like Ireland’s Ballymun initiative, reflecting the issue’s call for localized, EU-coordinated solutions to immediate employment crises.  
SD perfectly aligns with prioritizing psychological support for unemployed youth, as highlighted in regional cases like Norfolk, through the issue’s emphasis on personalized assessments and holistic service provision.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the severe youth unemployment crisis in the EU, citing a 23.4% youth unemployment rate (5.68 million young people) and 7.5 million NEETs (not in employment, education, or training) under 25, with inaction costing €153 billion annually (1.2% of EU GDP). It endorsed the Youth Guarantee scheme, urging member states to ensure all young people under 25 and recent graduates under 30 receive a quality offer of employment, education, apprenticeship, or traineeship within four months of unemployment or leaving education. The resolution emphasized aligning the scheme with Europe 2020 goals, including 75% employment for 20-64-year-olds, reducing early school-leaving below 10%, and lifting 20 million out of poverty. It called for EU funding, particularly allocating at least 25% of Structural Funds to the European Social Fund (ESF) to support implementation, while stressing balanced EU-national financing. The Parliament highlighted the need for personalized assessments, tailored services, and quality frameworks for education/training offers, including fair pay and working conditions. It urged cooperation between EU institutions, member states, social partners, and local authorities, and supported monitoring via an Employment Committee and the European Semester to track progress, name non-compliant states, and assist financially constrained members. Reforms in education and labor market policies were emphasized to address skills mismatches and precarious employment trends.

title: Tackling youth unemployment: possible ways out: REPORT on tackling youth unemployment: possible ways out
background: Persistently high youth unemployment rates across EU member states, exacerbated by economic crisis and regional disparities, alongside existing initiatives like the Youth Opportunities Initiative and Youth Guarantee, highlighted structural challenges including skills mismatches and labor market transitions. The Parliament will discuss EU-level strategies to address youth unemployment through policy coordination and targeted funding mechanisms.

stances.stance:
SD fundamentally sanctions the issue’s emphasis on structural reforms to bridge education-labor market gaps, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to dual education systems and vocational training as pathways to sustainable youth employment.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand to expedite implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative and Youth Guarantee Scheme, stressing that urgent budgetary approvals are critical to oxygenate EU programs combating NEETs and precarious work.  
SD fundamentally sanctions leveraging EU structural funds for SME support and green tech job creation, mirroring S&D’s manifesto priorities to foster youth entrepreneurship while condemning Council delays in releasing payments as undermining these goals.  
SD perfectly aligns with gender parity measures in the issue, including childcare access and anti-discrimination frameworks, and underscores that underfunding risks exacerbating the 22.9% unemployment rate among young women.  
SD fundamentally sanctions cross-border qualification recognition and second-chance education for NEETs, emphasizing that resolving the 2013 payment crisis is prerequisite to funding skills programs and preventing brain drain.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's reliance on austerity-driven EU budgets that perpetuate youth unemployment through chronic underfunding of social programs.  
GUE_NGL opposes the Youth Employment Initiative's framework as it operates within the same Multiannual Financial Framework they voted against, which slashed €6 billion needed for robust job guarantees.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to mandate wealth taxation for funding, leaving SME/job-creation measures dependent on structural funds vulnerable to member-state austerity cuts.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's silence on reversing privatization of education/vocational systems, which exacerbates labor market exclusion of NEETs and disabled youth.  
GUE_NGL notes the gender pay gap provisions lack binding targets and funding commitments, mirroring the MFF's childcare access failures they previously denounced.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the alarmingly high and regionally uneven youth unemployment rates (ranging from under 10% to over 60%) and the 14 million young people aged 15-30 classified as NEETs (not in education, employment, or training), alongside widespread precarious employment. It emphasized structural reforms to bridge education-labor market gaps, advocating for dual education systems, vocational training, and curricula aligned with labor needs, including ICT, entrepreneurship, and language skills. The resolution highlighted the €6 billion Youth Employment Initiative (2014-2020) and Youth Guarantee Scheme, urging Member States to expedite their implementation while stressing that funding remains insufficient. It called for leveraging EU structural funds (ESF, ERDF) to support SMEs, youth entrepreneurship, and job creation in high-growth sectors like green tech and ICT, alongside tax incentives for businesses hiring young people. Gender disparities were underscored, noting 22.9% youth unemployment among women and a 16.2% gender pay gap, with demands for childcare access, anti-discrimination measures, and targeted support for vulnerable groups, including migrants and disabled youth. The resolution urged quality frameworks for paid traineeships, monitoring systems for policy effectiveness, cross-border recognition of qualifications, and integration of NEETs through second-chance education and skills programs. It also stressed the need to address regional disparities, promote mobility, and combat brain drain through cohesive EU-wide strategies.

title: Social protection for all, including self-employed workers: REPORT on social protection for all, including self-employed workers
background: Rising self-employment rates, labor market fragmentation, and austerity-driven social spending cuts amid economic crises exacerbated gaps in social security coverage, disproportionately affecting vulnerable groups like women and youth. The Parliament will discuss extending equitable social protection to self-employed workers and addressing systemic disparities in EU social security frameworks.

stances.stance:
SD completely approves the issue’s emphasis on modernizing social security systems to include self-employed workers, perfectly aligning with their commitment to combat labor market segmentation and ensure universal access to healthcare, pensions, and unemployment benefits.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for gender equality measures, particularly the recognition of care periods in pension calculations and improved maternity protections, reflecting their dedication to addressing systemic disparities faced by women in precarious work.  
SD fully supports the issue’s push to integrate lifelong learning and youth employment initiatives, recognizing these as critical tools for economic stabilization and reducing social inequalities across EU member states.  
SD endorses the proposal to incentivize self-employment through temporary reductions in social contributions while safeguarding against false self-employment schemes, in line with their focus on sustainable labor policies and equitable social protection frameworks.  
SD applauds the emphasis on cross-border coordination of social security systems and collective insurance schemes for the self-employed, which aligns with their vision of a harmonized European social model rooted in solidarity and inclusive growth.

ECR rejects the premise that long-term self-employment should be normalized through enhanced social protections, viewing this as counterproductive to entrepreneurial growth and job creation.  
This completely rejects with ECR's position that social systems must prioritize incentivizing self-employed individuals to transition into employers who contribute to social security funds.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the need to maintain fiscal discipline by tying social entitlements to formal business expansion rather than individual status.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the issue's implicit framing of self-employment as an endpoint, arguing it contradicts their principle of fostering economic dynamism through scalable enterprises.  
ECR argues the issue's focus on individual social rights undermines labor market responsibility structures, creating disincentives for micro-enterprises to mature into larger employers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about ensuring universal access to adequate social protection across the EU, emphasizing its role in combating poverty, promoting labor market integration, and stabilizing economies. It highlighted that over 15% of EU employment in 2012 comprised self-employed workers, many facing inadequate social security, particularly women, who are disproportionately affected by pension gaps, precarious work, and care-related career breaks. The resolution urged Member States to modernize social security systems, ensure sustainable financing, and align reforms with ILO standards, including minimum income guarantees, access to healthcare, unemployment benefits, and pensions. It called for gender equality measures, such as recognizing care periods in pension calculations, improving maternity protections, and addressing discrimination in pay and social entitlements. Member States were urged to combat false self-employment, undeclared work, and labor market segmentation, while enhancing social protection for vulnerable groups, including youth, the elderly, and low-income families. The resolution stressed the need for affordable childcare, flexible work arrangements, lifelong learning, and collective insurance schemes for the self-employed. It advocated linking social rights to individuals rather than employment status, improving data collection on self-employment, and strengthening cross-border coordination of social security systems. Finally, it urged the Commission and Member States to integrate ILO Decent Work Agenda targets into EU policies and promote social dialogue to address labor market challenges while safeguarding the European social model.

title: Posting of workers in the framework of the provision of services: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the enforcement of directive 96/71/EC concerning the posting of workers in the framework of the provision of services
background: Inconsistent enforcement of the 1996 Posted Workers Directive across EU member states created challenges in balancing cross-border service provision with worker protections, prompting the European Commission’s 2012 proposal. The Parliament will discuss measures to strengthen compliance mechanisms and address discrepancies in applying labor standards for temporarily posted workers.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA completely supports the issue's measures to combat wage theft through mandatory minimum wage compliance in host countries, perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to eradicate worker exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's groundbreaking introduction of EU-wide contractor liability clauses, a policy priority since 2009, while advocating future expansion to all high-risk sectors beyond construction.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the issue's mandate for enhanced cross-border labor inspections and fraud penalties, operationalizing their 2011 "Fair Mobility" action plan against letterbox companies.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the critical enhancement opportunity to extend joint employer liability to agriculture and transport sectors during the 2025 directive review, as proposed by Member Delli.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes this directive as a vital step toward harmonized social standards through its worker information portals, a mechanism they first detailed in their 2013 Social Europe white paper.

GUE/NGL rejects the proposal as fundamentally inadequate in combating wage dumping and ensuring equal pay for equal work, contradicting their core principle of social justice.  
GUE/NGL opposes the closed-list approach to controls, which obstructs member states’ ability to address organized labor exploitation and criminal practices.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue’s failure to mandate general contractor liability, a critical mechanism to prevent corporate evasion of labor protections.  
GUE/NGL condemns the exclusion of pension and social benefit parity for posted workers, perpetuating systemic inequality across EU labor markets.  
GUE/NGL argues the directive prioritizes unrestricted service freedom over worker dignity, directly conflicting with their demand for binding social safeguards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0131) to align national legislation with Articles 53(1) and 62 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aimed at facilitating the internal market through freedom of establishment and services. The resolution, informed by the European Economic and Social Committee’s opinion of September 2012 and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs’ report (A7-0249/2013), emphasized the need for coherence with internal market principles and called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. It instructed the Parliament’s President to forward the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring procedural transparency and interinstitutional accountability.

title: Programme for social change and innovation: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European Union Programme for Social Change and Innovation
background: Persistent high unemployment and social exclusion rates across EU member states, alongside existing fragmented EU initiatives (PROGRESS, EURES, Microfinance Facility), prompted the 2011 Commission proposal to consolidate efforts under Europe 2020 strategy goals. The Parliament will discuss establishing a unified EU programme for employment support and social innovation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the integration of cross-border employment partnerships through EURES enhancements, aligning with their commitment to voluntary labor mobility and addressing skill mismatches within the EU.  
EPP approves the unified program structure while insisting on binding budget percentages for youth-focused initiatives like the Youth Guarantee, reflecting their transversal priority of combating youth unemployment.  
EPP endorses micro-financing mechanisms for social enterprises, proposing strengthened eligibility criteria to prioritize ventures demonstrating measurable community impact and job creation.  
EPP highlights the necessity of maintaining EURES pilot projects to improve transnational job matching systems, particularly for young professionals seeking opportunities abroad.  
EPP commends the program’s crisis-responsive design, urging member states to leverage its tools for economic recovery while preserving parliamentary oversight over budgetary allocations.

ALDE strongly advocates the Microfinance Facility as a vital tool for empowering disadvantaged entrepreneurs, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to inclusive economic growth and youth employment.  
ALDE applauds the integration of voluntary mobility monitoring through EURES, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of flexible labor markets while safeguarding against unintended social impacts.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the financial allocation to match original ambitions for all sub-programmes, ensuring sufficient risk-sharing capacity for micro-enterprises amid persistent credit access barriers.  
ALDE endorses the one-stop-shop approach for cross-border employment services, recognizing its potential to streamline EU mobility in line with single market principles.  
ALDE urges broader Member State participation in the Microfinance Facility, citing Ireland's success model as evidence of its added value for social innovation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the financial framework and resource allocation for EU priorities, emphasizing that the proposed financial envelope in the legislative proposal (COM(2011)0609) remains provisional pending agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). It stressed the necessity of increasing the next MFF budget by at least 5% above the 2013 level to address existing and emerging priorities, including social inclusion and obligations under the Treaty of Lisbon, while challenging the Council to justify any potential cuts to EU-funded projects with proven added value. The resolution highlighted the need for sufficient resources to respond to unforeseen challenges and urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments are introduced. It also noted objections from the Swedish Parliament on subsidiarity grounds and incorporated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of Regions.

title: Towards a job-rich recovery: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on ‘Towards a job-rich recovery’
background: Persistently high EU unemployment rates, exacerbated by economic stagnation, austerity measures, and structural labor market weaknesses, alongside divergences between member states and challenges in meeting the EU 2020 employment target, prompted parliamentary consideration. The Parliament will discuss strategies for job creation and labor market reforms to address unemployment and align with EU 2020 goals.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on structural labor market reforms and entrepreneurship as critical drivers for sustainable job creation, aligning with ALDE’s commitment to competitive, innovation-driven economies.  
ALDE applauds the focus on youth unemployment through skills development and a legally enforceable Youth Guarantee, which directly advances ALDE’s priority of empowering future generations in the labor market.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the issue by mandating an EU-wide impact assessment of labor laws to ensure reforms balance competitiveness with social protections, thereby strengthening the foundation for growth.  
ALDE endorses the European Investment Pact’s prioritization of green technology and SME growth, noting these sectors’ proven potential to generate employment while advancing ALDE’s sustainability agenda.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgency of leveraging the European Globalisation Fund for upskilling, urging Member States to adopt this tool as a key component of the job-rich recovery strategy.

ECR fundamentally againsts the issue's push for EU-wide labor harmonization, rejecting any establishment of European minimum wages as incompatible with national sovereignty in labor policy.  
ECR explicitly rejects the proposal for EU controls over Member States' labor markets, viewing this as a dangerous overreach that would stifle SME growth through bureaucratic interference.  
ECR opposes the issue’s reliance on centralized investment plans, arguing that sustainable job creation requires deregulation and tax cuts for SMEs rather than EU-directed sectoral initiatives.  
ECR condemns the issue’s regulatory approach to labor standards, asserting that measures like the Youth Guarantee impose inflexible burdens on employers and contradict subsidiarity principles.  
ECR disputes the premise that fiscal consolidation must be balanced with EU-mandated social investments, maintaining that austerity and market liberalization are superior pathways to recovery.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over rising EU unemployment, which increased from 9.5% in 2010 to 10.2% in 2012, resulting in 6 million job losses since 2008, and stressed the urgent need to create 17.6 million jobs by 2020 to meet the EU 2020 target of 75% employment for 20-64-year-olds. It highlighted systemic challenges, including youth unemployment, skills mismatches (with 40% of future jobs requiring high skills), and labor market segmentation exacerbated by austerity measures and inadequate reforms. The resolution called for a "European Investment Pact" to prioritize sustainable growth in sectors like green energy (potentially creating 2 million jobs via the Energy Efficiency Directive), ICT, and health/social services, alongside tax reforms to reduce the 40% average labor tax wedge and stimulate SME growth, which provides two-thirds of private sector jobs. It urged Member States to combat undeclared work, adopt National Job Plans aligned with EU 2020 targets, and implement a legally enforceable "Youth Guarantee" ensuring work or training within four months of unemployment. The Parliament emphasized leveraging EU funds (e.g., cohesion policy, EAFRD) for skills development, labor mobility via the EURES network, and mutual recognition of qualifications through a European Skills Passport. It advocated for fair labor standards, including minimum wages, gender equality, and protections against precarious work, while stressing the need to balance fiscal consolidation with growth-friendly investments in education, innovation, and social inclusion.

title: Assessment of the 2012 European Year for active ageing and solidarity between generations: REPORT on the Report on the implementation, results and overall assessment of the 2012 European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations
background: The European Union's aging population, projected to reach an average age over 50 by 2050, prompted the 2011 Council Decision establishing the 2012 European Year for Active Ageing. The Parliament will discuss the initiative's implementation assessment and challenges in promoting sustainable aging policies and intergenerational solidarity.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA completely accepts the issue's emphasis on concrete follow-up actions to the 2012 European Year, aligning perfectly with their commitment to translating policy initiatives into tangible social protections for older workers.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to utilize European financial instruments for reintegrating middle-aged workers, effectively advancing their priority of combating age-based employment discrimination through structural funding solutions.  

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the issue's rejection of solely linking retirement age to life expectancy, which mirrors their longstanding advocacy for labor market realities to inform pension policy reforms.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on addressing unemployment among pre-retirement populations as a key component of ensuring equitable active ageing strategies across EU member states.  

GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue's alignment with their vision for intergenerational solidarity through workplace adaptations and lifelong learning programs that value experienced workers' contributions.

GUE/NGL fundamentally rejects the issue's approach to pension reforms as incompatible with their commitment to universal public social security systems.  
GUE/NGL opposes the implied linkage between demographic ageing and retirement age increases, denouncing this as punitive to both older workers and unemployed youth.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's failure to prioritize eliminating precarious employment – a root cause of pension system strain – instead of shifting burdens to individuals.  
GUE/NGL conflicts fundamentally with the issue's tolerance of privatization risks in social security, which aligns with bank/insurer interests rather than intergenerational solidarity.  
GUE/NGL demands rejection of all measures framing extended working lives as a solution, insisting on dignified early retirement options for physically demanding professions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the challenges of an ageing population in the EU, projecting that by 2050 the average age will exceed 50, necessitating urgent action to address demographic shifts, social welfare demands, and sustainable public services. It emphasized active ageing as a societal asset, promoting intergenerational solidarity, non-discrimination, and lifecycle approaches to health, employment, and social inclusion. Key priorities included combating age-based discrimination in employment (noting Council Directive 2000/78/EC), reducing the 39% gender pension gap, and addressing poverty risks affecting 21% of older women. The resolution highlighted the need for accessible digital technologies, given 69% of those lacking basic digital skills are over 55, and urged inclusive strategies for the Digital Single Market. It called for sustainable pension systems, noting 75 million Europeans rely on occupational pension funds worth €2.5 trillion, and stressed reforms to ensure adequacy and equity, particularly for women. The Parliament advocated for EU-wide policies to support older workers through lifelong learning, generational mentoring, and workplace adaptations, while rejecting sole reliance on raising retirement ages. It endorsed the "silver economy" as a growth driver, urged improved healthcare access, and recommended EU strategies on dementia, demographic decline, and elder rights, including a potential UN Convention. Member States were urged to enhance public infrastructure, transport accessibility, and volunteering programs, leveraging EU funds like the European Social Fund. The resolution also demanded action on elder abuse, long-term care adequacy, and equitable health reforms, stressing data collection to monitor progress and ensure targeted interventions.

title: Employment and social policies in the euro area: REPORT on the employment and social policies of the euro area
background: Persistent unemployment disparities, particularly affecting youth and long-term jobseekers, alongside labor market segmentation, in-work poverty risks, and challenges in social protection systems, characterize euro area economies amid uneven post-crisis recovery. The Parliament will discuss strategies to enhance employment policies and social equity to address economic convergence and labor market integration within the euro area.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the issue’s focus on reducing youth unemployment and skills mismatches but advises amending Clause 9 to prioritize sector-specific vocational training partnerships with tech industries, ensuring education systems align with digitalization demands.  
EPP endorses the tripling of Erasmus+ funding and Youth Employment Initiative increases, aligning with EPP’s commitment to cross-border labor mobility and lifelong learning, but suggests adding regional allocation criteria to direct resources to high-unemployment areas like Greece and Spain.  
EPP advises strengthening the “silver rule” provision in fiscal policies by exempting not only childcare and youth programs but also regional cohesion funds, ensuring underdeveloped regions receive sustained social investment.  
EPP highlights the need to amend Section 5 to include concrete metrics for tracking gender pension gap reductions, reinforcing the issue’s alignment with EPP’s gender equality goals.  
EPP expresses concern that the issue’s labor market segmentation analysis lacks targeted measures for non-standard workers, urging explicit safeguards for part-time and gig economy employees in social security reforms.

ECR absolutely challenges the issue's failure to condemn austerity-driven fiscal policies that directly caused pension destruction and social collapse in Greece.  
ECR rejects the "silver rule" exemption framework as insufficient to prevent ongoing pension cuts, directly conflicting with their demand to halt all reductions to retiree incomes.  
The issue's social investment proposals overlook the catastrophic consequences of PSI measures on pension systems, contradicting ECR's insistence on debt restructuring to protect social funds.  
ECR denounces the absence of binding mechanisms to reverse austerity-era pension cuts, which left 33% of Greek retirees below 600€ monthly - irreconcilable with dignity guarantees in the European Pillar of Social Rights.  
This initiative fails to mandate recapitalization of plundered pension funds, directly opposing ECR's core demand for restitution of assets destroyed through EU/IMF programs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent socio-economic disparities in the euro area, noting uneven economic recovery despite favorable conditions, with unemployment at 8.3% (June 2018) but significant divergence among Member States, ranging from 3.4% in Germany to 20.2% in Greece. Youth unemployment remained high at 16.9%, exceeding 40% in Greece and Spain, while long-term unemployment accounted for 48.5% of total joblessness. The resolution highlighted labor market segmentation affecting women, youth, older workers, and marginalized groups, with 21.2% part-time employment (31.4% for women) and a 37% gender pension gap. Poverty and social exclusion affected 23.1% of the euro area population, with in-work poverty at 9.5%, stressing the need to meet Europe 2020 targets of 75% employment and reducing poverty by 20 million. Key recommendations included reforms to enhance social protection, ensure access to childcare, healthcare, and education, and implement the European Pillar of Social Rights (EPSR) through legislation and funding. The resolution urged Member States to prioritize quality job creation, reduce labor market inequalities, address skills mismatches via lifelong learning and vocational training, and adopt the Child Guarantee to combat child poverty. It called for tripling Erasmus+ funding, increasing the Youth Employment Initiative to €21 billion, and integrating a "silver rule" in fiscal policies to exempt social investments like childcare and youth programs from deficit calculations. Emphasis was placed on digital transformation, gender equality, sustainable pensions, and improving healthcare and long-term care systems. The cultural and creative sectors were highlighted as vital for job creation (7.5% of EU employment), while measures to counter brain drain, promote fair working conditions in sports, and enhance cross-sector labor mobility were also advocated.

title: Establishing a European Labour Authority: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Labour Authority
background: The European Union's single market principles facilitated cross-border labor mobility, with over 17 million citizens working or residing in another Member State by 2018, alongside challenges in enforcing EU labor laws and addressing social fraud. The Parliament will discuss establishing a centralized authority to enhance cross-border enforcement of labor regulations and social security coordination.

stances.stance:
SD entirely agrees the establishment of the European Labour Authority as a landmark achievement in combating labor exploitation and realizing the European Pillar of Social Rights, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to fair worker mobility and social justice.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on cross-border worker protections and undeclared work eradication, underscoring the necessity of parliamentary involvement in selecting the Authority's seat to ensure procedural legitimacy.  
SD highlights future enhancement opportunities such as establishing a pan-European labor inspection system and digital social security portability, while fully supporting the current issue's foundational role in preventing wage dumping.  
SD emphasizes the Authority's critical function in enforcing posted worker directives and enabling transnational data-sharing mechanisms, effectively advancing SD's priority of closing social security coverage gaps across member states.  
SD strongly advocates for Austria's candidacy as the ELA headquarters, reflecting the nation's frontline experience with wage disparity challenges, while celebrating the issue as a decisive victory against conservative resistance to labor protections.

ECR rejects the establishment of a European Labour Authority as absolutely opposeing with its commitment to subsidiarity and national sovereignty in labor market governance.  
ECR opposes the proposal’s centralization of oversight, arguing it duplicates national mechanisms while failing to address systemic violations of existing worker protections in member states.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the inefficacy of EU bureaucracy to improve practical working conditions, instead imposing new financial burdens on workers and employers.  
ECR condemns the issue’s disregard for member states’ competence to address labor issues locally, labeling the Authority a power grab inconsistent with proportionality principles.  
This initiative’s focus on bureaucratic expansion directly contradicts ECR’s stance that fewer EU institutions—not more—are needed to ensure labor market flexibility and national accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0131) on legislative measures tied to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, specifically Articles 46, 48, 53(1), 62, and 91(1), which address employment, social policy, transport, and internal market rules. It noted the Swedish Parliament’s reasoned opinion challenging compliance with subsidiarity principles and incorporated input from the European Economic and Social Committee (September 2019) and the Committee of the Regions (October 2018). The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading position, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text and instructing its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments.

title: Coordination of social security systems: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 on the coordination of social security systems and Regulation (EC) No 987/2009 laying down the procedure for implementing Regulation (EC) No 883/2004
background: Growing cross-border labor mobility and divergent national social security systems under the EU's 2004/2009 coordination framework prompted the European Commission's 2016 proposal to address administrative gaps, fraud risks, and unequal worker protections. The Parliament will discuss amendments to harmonize social security coordination rules for mobile workers and ensure benefit portability.

stances.stance:
ECR strongly accepts maintaining national jurisdiction over social security systems, aligning with their principle that benefit eligibility must strictly correlate with prior contributions to prevent welfare dependency.  
ECR proposes amending Article 12 to enforce a minimum three-month work period before accessing unemployment benefits, enhancing fraud prevention while preserving labor mobility.  
ECR approves limiting benefit portability to pensions only, as raised by Νότης Μαριάς, to avoid subsidizing lower-cost economies and protect systems like Greece’s from exploitation.  
ECR endorses stricter activation controls for exported unemployment benefits, urging Annex II revisions to require job-seeking proof in the host country, countering misuse risks highlighted by Helga Stevens.  
ECR recommends indexing benefits to cost-of-living differences when transferred abroad, addressing Anders Vistisen’s concern about disproportionate payouts in home countries.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposed child benefit indexation as fundamentally discriminatory against Eastern European workers who contribute equally to host countries' social systems.  
GUE_NGL opposes provisions allowing unemployment benefit exports after minimal work periods, warning this enables social dumping and destabilizes national solidarity-based systems like Denmark's.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to mandate full equality in social rights across borders, perpetuating second-class citizenship for mobile workers in contradiction to free movement principles.  
GUE_NGL disputes the coordination framework's compatibility with public welfare systems, citing parallel EU moves toward pension privatization and age-limit hikes that erode social protections.  
GUE_NGL demands rejection of all austerity-driven "sustainability" measures, insisting job creation and wage increases—not benefit restrictions—secure social systems' futures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2016)0815) concerning amendments to EU social security coordination rules under Article 48 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized compliance with subsidiarity principles, addressing concerns from the French Senate that the proposal might encroach on national competencies. The resolution incorporated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (July 2017) and the Committee of the Regions (July 2017), alongside input from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Petitions (report A8-0386/2018). Parliament adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial changes are made, and instructed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU objectives while respecting member states’ roles in social security systems.

title: Establishment of a European Platform to enhance cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on establishing a European Platform to enhance cooperation in the prevention and deterrence of undeclared work
background: Undeclared work across EU member states persisted as a significant economic and social challenge, undermining labor rights, distorting market competition, and reducing tax/social security revenues. Cross-border complexities and varying national enforcement capacities exacerbated systemic vulnerabilities. The Parliament will discuss establishing a cooperative framework to address undeclared work through enhanced transnational coordination and information-sharing mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP totally upholds the establishment of the European Platform as a critical tool to combat undeclared work, perfectly aligning with its commitment to social justice and fair competition within the Single Market.  
EPP emphasizes the platform’s role in preserving subsidiarity while fostering cross-border operational coordination, reflecting its principle of EU action only where member states cannot act alone.  
EPP applauds the inclusion of social partners in the platform’s structure, recognizing this as essential to addressing labor exploitation and ensuring worker protections.  
EPP highlights the platform’s focus on data-sharing and best-practice exchanges as a strategic enhancement to national enforcement systems, avoiding harmonization that could dilute effective controls.  
EPP underscores the issue’s alignment with fiscal responsibility, noting the platform’s cost-efficiency (€2.1M/year) and its potential to recover billions in lost tax/Social Security revenues.

ENF rejects the European Platform's approach as it fails to address the root causes of undeclared work, such as austerity policies and globalization, which render formal employment unsustainable for employers and workers.  
ENF opposes EU-level regulation, asserting that combating undeclared work requires national sovereignty through community preference, intelligent protectionism, and investment incentives rather than supranational bureaucracies.  
ENF fully challenges with the issue’s framework, arguing that open borders and uncontrolled migration—exacerbated by EU policies—create conditions for widespread labor fraud and undeclared work.  
ENF contends the proposal overlooks structural economic failures, including excessive social charges and lack of viable employment, which force workers and employers into informal arrangements.  
ENF dismisses the Platform’s efficacy, citing the EU’s inability to regulate digital economy loopholes and porous external borders that enable undeclared labor markets to thrive.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2014 proposal (COM(2014)0221) by adopting its first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the proposal are planned. It highlighted concerns from the UK House of Commons, which contested the proposal’s compliance with subsidiarity principles, and incorporated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (September 2014) and the Committee of the Regions (October 2014). The resolution instructed the Parliament’s President to communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, while underscoring the role of parliamentary committees—including Employment and Social Affairs, Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and Women’s Rights and Gender Equality—in shaping the legislative response. Procedural elements like Treaty references and voting protocols were acknowledged but excluded from substantive focus.

title: European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF)
background: The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, operational since 2007 to aid workers affected by globalisation-related restructuring, experienced low uptake despite annual funding availability, attributed to procedural complexity and high eligibility thresholds. The Parliament will discuss revising the fund’s scope, accessibility, and responsiveness to technological and ecological transitions impacting labor markets.

stances.stance:
EFDD totally conflicts with the EGF's budgetary mechanism, opposing the "strings-attached" rebate system that penalizes national contributions post-Brexit.  
EFDD rejects the proposal's assumption of EU-level resource allocation, citing inefficiency in "sending money to the EU only to reclaim partial funds with conditionalities".  
The issue overlooks critical sovereignty concerns by extending EGF applicability beyond Brexit transition periods, contradicting EFDD's principle of disentangling UK-EU fiscal obligations.  
EFDD conditionally endorses gender-responsive budgeting provisions only if accompanied by strict national oversight clauses to prevent EU overreach.  
This fails to address EFDD's core objection that post-2021 EU structural funds inherently lack democratic accountability for non-member states.

SD fully agrees the issue’s emphasis on rapid regional support for mass job losses, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to solidarity and equitable resource allocation in crisis-hit communities.  
SD perfectly aligns with the lowered activation threshold for the EGF, ensuring smaller regions and enterprises receive critical aid, as advocated in the issue’s amendments to strengthen social cohesion.  
SD fully agrees transforming the EGF into a pillar of sustainable transition, advancing S&D’s vision of integrating ecological justice with worker protection through targeted budgetary controls.  
SD highlights the issue’s robust safeguards for gender-responsive budgeting and regional development, which mirror S&D’s demands for inclusive, future-proof labor market policies.  
SD underscores the EGF’s role as a model for post-Brexit solidarity, urging continued EU-wide commitment to shielding workers from globalization’s disruptions in line with the issue’s objectives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0380) concerning legislative measures under Article 175(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing alignment with EU social and economic cohesion objectives. It adopted amendments reflecting inputs from multiple committees, including Employment and Social Affairs, International Trade, Budgets, and Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, to strengthen provisions on equitable resource allocation, transparency, and gender-responsive budgeting. The resolution underscored the need for robust budgetary controls and regional development safeguards, urging the Commission to integrate parliamentary amendments into revised proposals. It mandated that the Commission re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial changes to the original text, ensuring legislative coherence and accountability. The adopted position was forwarded to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments for further action.

title: Pathways for the reintegration of workers recovering from injury and illness into quality employment: REPORT on pathways for the reintegration of workers recovering from injury and illness into quality employment
background: Europe's aging workforce faces rising chronic health conditions and work-related stress, with disparities in workplace adaptability and social inclusion under EU frameworks like the European Pillar of Social Rights and UN disability conventions. The Parliament will discuss reintegrating workers recovering from injury/illness into employment amid demographic shifts and occupational health challenges.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the EU-wide enforcement of anti-discrimination laws as outlined in the issue, arguing that such measures constitute undue interference in national legislation and risk stifling France's ability to pursue future advancements in worker reintegration policies.  
ENF opposes the harmonization of reintegration strategies across Member States, viewing the issue's push for EU-level frameworks as enabling social dumping by nations with weaker labor protections rather than strengthening them.  
The proposal fully disapproves with ENF's commitment to national sovereignty by imposing standardized occupational safety requirements on SMEs, which the party believes should remain under exclusive national jurisdiction to preserve economic flexibility.  
ENF condemns the issue's emphasis on centralized data-driven policies, asserting that it overlooks critical aspects of local labor market dynamics and undermines France's existing effective practices in managing aging workforce challenges.  
The issue's advocacy for EU funding mechanisms to dictate reintegration initiatives is inconsistent with ENF's principle of fiscal autonomy, risking dependency on supranational structures that erode member states' decision-making capacities.

SD entirely promotes the issue’s mandate for robust anti-discrimination enforcement and workplace adaptations, perfectly aligning with SD’s decades-long advocacy for disability rights and equitable labor participation.  
SD perfectly aligns with the emphasis on psychosocial risk mitigation and mental health destigmatization, advancing SD’s vision of comprehensive occupational health frameworks rooted in prevention and early intervention.  
SD fully supports the prioritization of tailored return-to-work programs and SME resource allocation, reflecting SD’s unwavering commitment to social solidarity and sustainable employment ecosystems.  
SD endorses the issue’s demand for improved social security protections for terminally ill workers and unpaid caregivers, resonating deeply with SD’s gender equality and social welfare agenda.  
SD applauds the integration of digital upskilling initiatives for older workers, aligning seamlessly with SD’s innovation-driven strategies to future-proof Europe’s aging workforce.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about work-related stress, affecting 25% of workers and accounting for nearly half of lost working days, and highlighted challenges posed by an aging workforce and chronic diseases, which impact 28% of Europeans. It emphasized the need for robust enforcement of anti-discrimination laws, including Directive 2000/78/EC, to ensure workplace adaptations for people with disabilities or chronic conditions, and called for EU-wide strategies to address psychosocial risks, mental health stigma, and substance abuse, noting that 20-25% of workplace accidents involve alcohol. The resolution urged Member States to prioritize prevention, early intervention, and rehabilitation, including tailored return-to-work programs, flexible working arrangements, and support for SMEs, which often lack resources for occupational safety. It stressed the economic and social benefits of reintegration, citing reduced welfare costs and improved well-being, and advocated for data-driven policies, EU-wide campaigns on musculoskeletal disorders, and digital skills training to aid older workers. The Parliament also highlighted disparities in income for people with disabilities (12% lower on average) and the urgent need to address unemployment among cancer patients, 21.8% of whom lose jobs post-diagnosis. It called for improved social security systems, protection for terminally ill workers, and recognition of unpaid caregivers, predominantly women, who face reduced employment prospects. The resolution underscored the importance of EU funding, including the ESF, for innovative reintegration initiatives and urged the Commission to develop a post-2020 Health and Safety Framework prioritizing these goals.

title: European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the Annual Growth Survey 2019: REPORT on European Semester for economic policy coordination: Employment and Social Aspects in the Annual Growth Survey 2019
background: Persistent economic growth and rising employment in the EU coexist with disparities in labor market outcomes, youth unemployment, in-work poverty, gender gaps, and challenges posed by digitalization and climate change. The Parliament will discuss integrating employment and social policies into the European Semester’s economic coordination framework through the 2019 Annual Growth Survey.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fundamentally accepts the issue’s integration of climate resilience priorities, perfectly aligning with their commitment to decarbonizing industry and energy systems as essential for sustainable growth.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on fiscal space for resilient infrastructure investments, mirroring their manifesto demands to address climate-related economic shocks through robust public services.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to modernize transport and energy sectors, recognizing this as critical to reducing the €153 billion annual cost of climate inaction highlighted in the issue.  
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s climate-proofing of the European Semester, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for environmental sustainability as a pillar of social equity.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the prioritization of decarbonization investments, which directly advances their goal of aligning economic governance with the Paris Agreement’s urgency.

ECR rejects the issue’s centralized approach to pension reforms, which totally disapproves with their principle that social security systems must remain under exclusive national sovereignty.  
ECR opposes the European Semester’s macroeconomic oversight mechanisms, viewing them as coercive tools to impose austerity and fiscal adjustments inconsistent with member states’ sovereign economic policymaking.  
The issue’s emphasis on EU-level social convergence overlooks critical aspects of subsidiarity, as stressed by ECR, particularly in areas like wage policy and labor market reforms reserved for national governments.  
ECR challenges the issue’s alignment with the Stability and Growth Pact, citing systemic flaws and selective enforcement that disproportionately target certain member states, undermining fair economic governance.  
ECR condemns the implicit expansion of EU competence into demographic and pension policies, arguing this violates treaty boundaries and exacerbates distrust in the EU’s respect for national sovereignty.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities regarding employment, social inclusion, and gender equality in the EU, emphasizing the need to address disparities and align policies with the European Pillar of Social Rights. It noted the 2017 EU employment rate of 73.2% for those aged 20-64, nearing the Europe 2020 target of 75%, but highlighted persistent challenges, including a youth unemployment rate of 18.6%, with NEETs costing €153 billion annually compared to the €21 billion Youth Guarantee budget (2017-2020). The resolution underscored rising precarious work, with part-time employment increasing from 16.8% to 18.7% (2008-2017), and in-work poverty at 9.6%, disproportionately affecting women. Despite a slight decline, 22.5% of the population remained at risk of poverty or social exclusion (AROPE), with child poverty rates higher in single-parent households. Gender gaps persisted, including a 12% employment gap, 16% pay gap, and 37% pension gap, exacerbated by women’s disproportionate care responsibilities (75% of unpaid care work). The resolution called for enhanced social protection, investment in affordable childcare, healthcare, and education, and urged Member States to address housing exclusion, with overcrowding rates exceeding the EU average in ten countries. It stressed the need for climate action, including decarbonization investments, and advocated integrating gender mainstreaming into economic policies, such as through gender budgeting and the Gender Equality Index. Other priorities included reducing skills mismatches (40% of adults lack basic digital skills), supporting SMEs, ensuring fair taxation, and improving work-life balance via accessible care services and the adoption of relevant directives. The resolution emphasized the European Semester’s role in promoting social convergence, sustainable growth, and upward economic mobility while tackling inequalities through structural reforms and targeted social investments.

title: European Social Fund Plus (ESF+): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+)
background: The European Commission proposed merging the European Social Fund, Youth Employment Initiative, and Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived into the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) to streamline EU social investments amid persistent unemployment, poverty, and regional disparities. The Parliament will discuss the ESF+ structure and funding priorities for 2021-2027.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA completely agrees the issue’s demand for structural coherence in ESF+ programming, perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to combat social divides through targeted regional anti-poverty initiatives.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the emphasis on civil society participation in ESF+ projects, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for grassroots partnerships in social justice interventions.  
GREEN_EFA completely agrees the condemnation of undefined operational objectives for poverty reduction, as this directly advances their priority to institutionalize measurable social rights safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to address material deprivation across all ESF+ strands, mirroring their 2023 electoral pledge to eradicate energy and housing poverty EU-wide.  
GREEN_EFA completely agrees the issue’s focus on synergies between funding strands, recognizing this as critical to fulfilling their vision of a Social Union with integrated solidarity mechanisms.

ECR partly supports the ESF+ proposal but requests revisions to Article 4 to explicitly mandate investment in Roma inclusion programs and SME support mechanisms, which the current text overlooks.  
ECR firmly opposes with the issue’s failure to address child poverty reduction targets in direct management strands, contradicting ECR’s emphasis on intergenerational equity.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as digital skills gap interventions, inconsistent with ECR’s priority on workforce readiness for global competitiveness.  
ECR objects to the absence of binding provisions for member-state flexibility in transnational cooperation funding, a core principle in ECR’s subsidiarity framework.  
 While supporting poverty elimination goals, ECR warns the issue’s undefined performance metrics for social innovation undermine accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) proposal’s lack of clarity and coherence, particularly regarding the shared management strand’s undefined specific objectives and priorities, which risk creating uncertainty in programming, monitoring, and evaluation under the forthcoming Common Provisions Regulation (CPR). It criticized the proposal’s failure to align objectives across strands, noting inconsistencies such as the exclusion of "addressing material deprivation through food" from direct/indirect management and the absence of operational objectives for "promoting social integration of people at risk of poverty" under these strands. The resolution highlighted the absence of mechanisms to ensure synergies between the three strands (shared, direct, and indirect management) and questioned the unclear provisions for reallocating resources between them, warning of potential duplication or gaps in support amid scarce budgetary resources. It further emphasized ESF+’s critical role in safeguarding social rights amid expanded responsibilities and condemned the lack of performance indicators and monitoring provisions for the Employment and Social Innovation strand, which undermines effective programming and accountability. The Parliament urged structural revisions to ensure coherence, avoid overlaps, and strengthen the fund’s capacity to address social challenges comprehensively.

title: European network of Employment Services, workers' access to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European network of Employment Services, workers' access to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets
background: The European Employment Services (EURES) network, established to facilitate cross-border labor mobility, faced challenges in addressing regional unemployment disparities, skills mismatches, and 2 million unfilled EU vacancies amid low intra-EU worker mobility rates (3%). The Parliament will discuss enhancing EURES to improve labor market integration and cross-border employment access.

stances.stance:
ENF fundamentally rejects the centralized EURES framework as creating surveillance tools that expose member states' economic vulnerabilities to external competitors.  
ENF opposes institutionalizing worker mobility requirements that enable "mobility blackmail" against unemployed citizens under Article 4's job-matching protocols.  
ENF condemns the issue's failure to prioritize SME-driven local job creation, contradicting their core principle of subsidiarity in labor market policies.  
ENF highlights the proposal's logistical incoherence in automating CV-job matching across 28 regulatory regimes during economic crises, as criticized in Recital 9.  
ENF asserts that cross-border workforce data pooling under Chapter III disproportionately empowers private entities to exploit regional wage disparities.

GREEN_EFA firmly upholds the enhanced role of EURES advisers in providing personalised support, perfectly aligning with their commitment to informed worker mobility across EU labour markets.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s strengthened non-discrimination safeguards, advancing their priority of equitable access to mobility services while upholding data protection standards.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s success in embedding social justice principles, reflecting their foundational advocacy for worker-centric policymaking in cross-border employment.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the inter-institutional collaboration demonstrated, which mirrors their values of constructive EU governance to achieve progressive labour market integration.  
GREEN_EFA recognises this agreement as a model implementation of their vision for rights-based mobility frameworks that balance opportunity with worker protections.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2014 proposal (COM(2014)0006) concerning amendments to the EU’s legal framework, as outlined in Article 46 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It adopted its first-reading stance based on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs’ report (A8-0224/2015) and incorporated the Committee on Regional Development’s opinion, emphasizing alignment with social and regional policy objectives. The resolution urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial changes to the original text, ensuring legislative transparency. It referenced consultations with the European Economic and Social Committee (June 2014) and the Committee of the Regions (June 2014), underscoring stakeholder input. The Parliament instructed its President to formally transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional cooperation under the ordinary legislative procedure.

title: Maternity leave: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on maternity leave
background: The 1992 Maternity Leave Directive, a 2008 proposal to extend protections, prolonged interinstitutional negotiations, and persistent EU gender employment, pay, and pension gaps, alongside aging populations and declining birth rates, underpin discussions. The Parliament will discuss revising maternity leave policies to address gender equality, work-life balance, and demographic challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's approach to maternity leave extensions as fully conflicting with EPP's principle of subsidiarity in family policy matters.  
EPP opposes EU-level mandates for 18-week maternity leaves, citing Anna Maria Corazza Bildt's argument that this imposes a "one-size-fits-all solution" incompatible with diverse national social systems.  
The proposal's separate paternity leave directive contradicts EPP members' repeated emphasis on shared parental responsibility over gender-specific mandates.  
EPP highlights the issue's failure to address economic realities, as noted by Dubravka Šuica, where poorer member states paradoxically maintain stronger social protections without EU interference.  
 While some EPP members support health protections for pregnant workers, the group unanimously opposes using workplace safety directives as "tools for European family policy engineering" (Anna Záborská).

SD fundamentally promotes the issue’s urgency in breaking the Council’s deadlock, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to gender equality and workers’ rights through immediate adoption of the revised Maternity Leave Directive.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands to establish binding EU-wide paternity leave standards, emphasizing this as critical to dismantling structural inequalities in care responsibilities and labor market participation.  
SD fundamentally promotes Parliament’s rejection of any REFIT-driven withdrawal attempt, framing continued Council inaction as incompatible with Europe’s demographic sustainability goals and social justice imperatives.  
SD unequivocally supports integrating pregnancy protections into the Europe 2020 strategy, recognizing the issue’s alignment with SD’s cross-border solidarity principles for economic empowerment of women.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for Commission mediation to resolve the 20-year legislative stagnation, emphasizing this as essential to fulfilling SD’s manifesto pledge for modernized EU social safeguards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent gender inequalities, including women’s higher poverty rates—with average pensions 39% lower than men’s—and disproportionate domestic burdens, as women spend three times more hours weekly on household and care tasks than men. It highlighted the stagnation in revising the Maternity Leave Directive (92/85/EEC), urging Member States to resume negotiations and calling on the Commission to mediate to resolve the Council’s deadlock, which risks derailing the legislative process. The resolution emphasized the need to address demographic challenges, such as declining birth rates exacerbated by economic uncertainty, and advocated for improved protections for pregnant workers and those who recently gave birth or are breastfeeding. It proposed a separate directive mandating at least 10 days of paid paternity leave and criticized the lack of such leave in a quarter of EU countries. Additionally, Parliament called for revising the Parental Leave Directive (2010/18/EU) to better support work-life balance, citing its failure to reduce gender gaps in pay, pensions, and poverty. It opposed potential withdrawal of the Maternity Leave Directive revision under the REFIT program, demanding alternative legislative action during the Luxembourg Council presidency. The resolution underscored the Europe 2020 targets of 75% employment and lifting 20 million people from poverty, stressing that gender equality is essential to achieving these goals. The text was forwarded to the Council and Commission for action.

title: Minimum income policies as a tool for fighting poverty: REPORT on minimum income policies as a tool for fighting poverty
background: Persistent poverty affecting 119 million in the EU, austerity-driven social spending cuts post-2008 crisis, and divergent national minimum income schemes prompted evaluation of anti-poverty measures. The Parliament will discuss minimum income policies' role in addressing poverty and social exclusion.

stances.stance:
ENF fully doubts the creation of a European minimum income scheme managed by EU institutions, viewing it as a direct threat to national sovereignty over social policy.  
ENF rejects the issue’s reliance on EU funding mechanisms like the European Social Fund, arguing this entrenches supranational control over member states’ fiscal and welfare decisions.  
The proposal conflicts with ENF’s principle that anti-poverty measures must remain under exclusive national authority, such as France’s RSA, to reflect local economic conditions.  
ENF opposes the replacement of nationally tailored systems with a standardized EU framework, which they argue would erode member states’ ability to address poverty through culturally specific policies.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of ENF’s platform, particularly its rejection of EU-level governance in social protections, which they equate to bureaucratic overreach incompatible with national autonomy.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s push for binding EU-wide minimum income schemes, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to eradicate poverty through dignified living standards above 60% of national median income as advocated by Nicola Caputo and Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto.  
SD approves integrating active labor policies with financial support systems, effectively advancing SD’s priority to combine job training and decent work opportunities with social protections per Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto’s emphasis on holistic anti-poverty strategies.  
SD endorses harmonized EU income benchmarks to dramatically reduce wage disparities, directly supporting Csaba Molnár’s demand for equal pay equity and systemic reduction of working poverty across member states.  
SD strongly sanctions using updated reference budgets and poverty metrics, as urged by Viorica Dăncilă, to tailor policies to national contexts while maintaining EU-wide cohesion and robust social safeguards.  
SD proposes enhancing the issue by initiating EU-funded evaluations of basic income pilots, responding to Agnes Jongerius’ call for innovative approaches while affirming contributory solidarity principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent poverty and social exclusion in the EU, noting that 119 million people (25% of the population) remain at risk, with 4 million experiencing homelessness annually. It emphasized the failure to meet the Europe 2020 target of reducing poverty by 20 million and highlighted rising inequalities exacerbated by austerity policies, which weakened social protections and public services. The resolution called on Member States to establish or strengthen **adequate minimum income schemes** ensuring a dignified standard of living, set above 60% of national median income and complemented by access to healthcare, education, housing, and active labor market policies. It stressed the need for **reference budgets** to tailor support to household needs and address disparities, while urging simplification of fragmented systems and improved benefit take-up to combat non-access (e.g., due to bureaucracy or stigma). The Parliament advocated using EU funds, including the European Social Fund, to support these schemes and monitor progress via the European Semester. It criticized austerity-driven cuts to social spending and unemployment benefits, linking these to increased poverty, and underscored the role of **fair tax policies** and anti-evasion measures to fund robust social systems. Additionally, the resolution highlighted the importance of **public employment programs** for vulnerable groups, integrating decent wages and training, and reaffirmed the necessity of social investment to stimulate economic growth and cohesion. Specific attention was given to children, single parents, and marginalized communities, urging alignment with ILO standards and the European Pillar of Social Rights to ensure universal access to essential services and reduce systemic inequalities.

title: Reducing inequalities with a special focus on child poverty: REPORT on reducing inequalities with a special focus on child poverty
background: Persistent child poverty rates in the EU, exceeding 26 million children at risk in 2013, linked to unemployment, inadequate social protections, and disparities in education and healthcare access amid economic crises and widening regional inequalities. The Parliament will discuss strategies to reduce inequalities, particularly addressing child poverty through policy frameworks and resource allocation.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA totally endorses the issue’s emphasis on universal access to nutrition, education, and healthcare as a critical step toward eradicating child poverty, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to children’s rights and social justice.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the urgency of addressing country-specific disparities exemplified by Hungary’s severe child hunger crisis, urging Member States to leverage the issue’s framework for tailored interventions under EU cohesion policies.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the proposed Child Guarantee as a transformative tool to combat energy poverty and malnutrition, which directly mirrors their 2023 manifesto priorities for equitable resource distribution.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need for robust implementation of EU Structural Funds to ensure no child faces institutional neglect, particularly in states where austerity policies have eroded social protections.  
GREEN_EFA stresses that the issue’s multidimensional indicators must catalyze accountability for governments failing to act, such as Hungary’s dismissal of civil initiatives tackling daily child hunger.

ECR rejects the binding EU sub-target to reduce child poverty as incompatible with subsidiarity principles, arguing centralized benchmarks undermine national welfare sovereignty  
ECR absolutely conflicts expanding universal public services through the Child Guarantee, asserting this creates unsustainable fiscal burdens and "discourages self-reliance through perpetual welfare dependency"  
ECR opposes increased reliance on EU Structural Funds for social protections, warning this redistributive approach "penalizes productive economies to subsidize failed policies elsewhere"  
ECR rejects issue clauses promoting minimum income schemes, stating they "distort labor markets and disincentivize parental employment contrary to merit-based prosperity"

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over alarming child poverty rates in the EU, noting that 26.5 million children (28% of under-18s) faced poverty or social exclusion in 2013, with risks exacerbated by economic crises, social inequalities, and inadequate welfare systems. It highlighted disparities across Member States, including rising malnutrition and school dropout rates (over 20% in Portugal, Spain, and Malta), and emphasized that children in single-parent households (49.8% at risk) and those with low parental work intensity (56.7% higher risk) were disproportionately affected. The resolution urged Member States to prioritize child-focused policies under the Europe 2020 strategy, including access to adequate resources, quality services (education, healthcare, housing), and child participation, while leveraging EU Structural Funds and implementing the Commission’s 2013 recommendation "Investing in Children." Key measures included establishing a binding EU sub-target to reduce child poverty, ensuring universal access to early childhood education (below 15% coverage in 11 countries), and adopting multidimensional indicators to assess deprivation. It called for strengthened social protections, including minimum income schemes, affordable childcare, and labor policies supporting parental employment, while opposing austerity-driven cuts to public services. The resolution also stressed addressing energy poverty, malnutrition, and housing insecurity (17% of EU children in unsafe housing) and advocated for a "Child Guarantee" to ensure free healthcare, education, and nutrition for disadvantaged children. Member States were urged to transition from institutional care to family-based support, promote inclusive education, and integrate migrant and marginalized children into social policies. Finally, it emphasized the economic cost of child poverty and the need for cross-sectoral, rights-based approaches to break intergenerational cycles of disadvantage.

title: Implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility: REPORT on implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility
background: The European Progress Microfinance Facility, established in 2010, aimed to enhance access to microloans for unemployed and marginalized groups amid post-2008 financial constraints. Evaluations identified uneven geographic reach, challenges in targeting vulnerable demographics, and gaps in social impact data. The Parliament will discuss the instrument's implementation and alignment with EU employment and inclusion objectives.

stances.stance:
SD totally upholds the issue's emphasis on expanding non-bank microfinance intermediaries to amplify credit access for refugees, disabled individuals, and unemployed populations, perfectly aligning with S&D's social equity agenda.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call to integrate Progress Facility objectives into the EaSI program, particularly its demand to prioritize social economy enterprises as engines for generative welfare and quality job creation.  
SD totally upholds targeted strategies to achieve 40:60 gender balance in microloan distribution, emphasizing enhanced outreach to women facing systemic unemployment barriers as outlined in S&D's gender justice framework.  
SD strongly approves the issue's geographical equity focus, urging intensified promotion of microcredits in peripherally disadvantaged regions like Southern Italy to counteract demographic decline through youth entrepreneurship.  
SD perfectly aligns with leveraging mentoring programs to increase micro-enterprise viability, transforming the 44% short-term survival rate into sustained economic participation through S&D-backed skills development frameworks.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the Facility’s emphasis on combating unemployment through microloan accessibility, aligning with their commitment to economic justice and equitable resource distribution for marginalized groups.
