GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s gender balance targets and urges accelerated implementation of outreach programs to address systemic barriers faced by women, particularly in regions with entrenched poverty disparities.  

GUE_NGL proposes enhancing grassroots collaboration with trade unions and community organizations to improve awareness of microfinance options among refugees and persons with disabilities, ensuring equitable access beyond urban centers.  

GUE_NGL emphasizes that while endorsing microfinance as a tool, member states must concurrently strengthen public welfare systems to prevent corporate-driven solutions from replacing state obligations in poverty eradication.  

GUE_NGL endorses leveraging ESF synergies to subsidize mentorship programs, addressing the 44% micro-enterprise failure rate through structured support rather than relying solely on individual entrepreneurial success.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of the European Progress Microfinance Facility (Facility) in addressing unemployment, social exclusion, and economic disparities by providing microloans to vulnerable groups, including the unemployed, at-risk individuals, and micro-enterprises, with a target of disbursing 46,000 loans (€500 million) by 2020. It highlighted the Facility’s role in job preservation and supporting labor market entry, though noted lower-than-expected employment creation due to concurrent economic crises. Gender disparities were emphasized, with only 36% female beneficiaries despite women facing higher unemployment and poverty rates, urging targeted strategies to achieve a 40:60 gender balance. Concerns included limited outreach to minorities, migrants, refugees, and persons with disabilities, insufficient awareness of the Facility (evidenced by lower-than-targeted microloan volumes, particularly in Italy), and gaps in social impact reporting. The resolution called for improved data transparency, simplified procedures for microfinance intermediaries (MFIs), synergies with EU funds like the European Social Fund (ESF), and enhanced training and mentoring to boost business viability, noting that 44% of supported micro-enterprises survived less than a year. It stressed expanding geographical coverage beyond 22 Member States, increasing support for the social economy, and addressing high application rejection rates (nearly 2,000 rejections, often due to over-indebtedness). Recommendations included leveraging the more flexible EaSI program to address shortcomings, prioritizing vulnerable groups, and ensuring equitable access to foster economic growth and social cohesion.

title: Pre-financing of operational programmes supported by the Youth Employment Initiative: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1304/2013 of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Social Fund, as regards an increase of the initial pre-financing amount paid to operational programmes supported by the Youth Employment Initiative
background: Persistently high youth unemployment in EU regions exceeding 25%, coupled with structural implementation delays in Youth Employment Initiative programmes due to limited initial pre-financing (1%), created funding bottlenecks for member states facing liquidity constraints. The Parliament will discuss amending the European Social Fund Regulation to adjust pre-financing rates for youth employment operational programmes.

EFDD requests revisions to Article 4 to mandate real-time public tracking of fund utilization, addressing the "empty box" criticism of opaque program administration.

EFDD warns that pre-financing expansions risk deepening public skepticism unless paired with structural reforms to prevent bureaucratic waste.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the 2015 Commission proposal (COM(2015)0046) concerning EU policy under Article 164 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting the proposal at first reading without amendments. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial changes or replacements to the proposal are planned, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural accountability. The resolution integrated inputs from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs’ report (A8-0134/2015) and the Committee on Culture and Education’s opinion, while acknowledging the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2015 advisory role and the Committee on Budgets’ financial compatibility assessment. Parliament instructed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional collaboration and adherence to EU legislative frameworks.

title: Social entrepreneurship and social innovation in combatting unemployment: REPORT on Social Entrepreneurship and Social Innovation in combating unemployment
background: Persistent high unemployment, particularly long-term and youth unemployment, alongside rising poverty and social exclusion in the EU following the 2008 financial crisis, coupled with unmet Europe 2020 employment targets and demographic aging, highlighted challenges in labor market integration. The Parliament will discuss social entrepreneurship and innovation strategies to address unemployment and economic inclusion.

EPP proposes enhancing SME access to ESF funds through simplified application procedures while maintaining strong support for financing mechanisms outlined in Articles 9-11.  
EPP endorses strict anti-precarity measures as highlighted by David Casa and Claude Rolin, urging clearer definitions of "atypical contracts" in Annex B to prevent exploitation while preserving labor market flexibility.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of the social and solidarity-based economy (SSE) in addressing unemployment, social exclusion, and sustainable growth, noting it employs over 14 million people (6.5% of the EU workforce) and comprises 2 million enterprises (10% of EU businesses). It highlighted the sector’s resilience during the crisis, creating 1.3 million jobs in health and social services (2009–2013), and its potential to meet Europe 2020 targets, including 75% employment and reducing poverty by 20 million people. The resolution urged swift implementation of the 2012 Social Business Initiative and expansion of EU support, emphasizing SSE’s democratic governance, social reinvestment, and focus on marginalized groups. It called for improved access to public procurement through social clauses and MEAT criteria, better financing via EU funds (EaSI, ESF, microcredit), and legal frameworks, including a potential EU statute for SSE entities. The Parliament stressed the need for education, training, and entrepreneurship programs targeting youth, women, and disadvantaged groups, alongside enhanced data collection, visibility, and platforms for best practices. It also advocated tax incentives, state aid flexibility, and integration of SSE into National Reform Programmes to boost job creation, social innovation, and cohesion, particularly in sectors like green and digital economies.

title: Transparent and predictable working conditions in the European Union: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on transparent and predictable working conditions in the European Union
background: Evolving labor markets, digitalization, and the rise of non-standard employment forms (e.g., platform work, on-demand contracts) prompted calls to modernize EU labor protections. The 1991 Written Statement Directive, deemed outdated amid growing atypical work arrangements, and the 2017 European Pillar of Social Rights necessitated reforms. The Parliament will discuss updating EU labor standards to enhance transparency and predictability in working conditions.

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's compensation requirements for canceled shifts, recognizing this as a landmark defense against algorithmic abuse of on-demand workers.  
The issue's rejection of blanket exemptions for public sector workers resonates completely with GREEN_EFA's manifesto pledge to universalize labor protections across all EU employment sectors.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the issue's binding timeline for employer disclosures as a critical fulfillment of their 2023 "Transparency Now" legislative priority.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2017 proposal (COM(2017)0797) concerning EU labor standards, emphasizing the need to align legislation with Treaty principles, particularly Article 153 on social policy. It noted the Swedish Parliament’s subsidiarity objection, arguing the proposal overstepped EU competence, and incorporated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (May 2018) and the Committee of the Regions (July 2018). The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended and instructing its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity while addressing substantive concerns over legal coherence and subsidiarity.

title: Economic policies of the euro area 2020: REPORT on economic policies of the euro area 2020 | A9-0193/2020 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic triggered a severe economic contraction in the euro area, reversing pre-crisis fiscal consolidation and intensifying unemployment, debt, and investment challenges. Existing EU frameworks, including the Stability and Growth Pact, faced strain amid coordinated crisis responses. The Parliament will discuss euro area economic policy coordination, recovery strategies, and governance reforms.

stances.stance:
SD strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on counter-cyclical fiscal policies and revising the Stability and Growth Pact, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to equitable crisis recovery and social investment frameworks.  
SD applauds the prioritization of binding social objectives like higher minimum wages and secure contracts, which mirror Agnes Jongerius’ call to center policies on human dignity rather than corporate interests.  
SD proposes enhancing the automatic stabilizer mechanism mentioned by Jonás Fernández to institutionalize crisis-responsive fiscal tools, ensuring sustained support beyond temporary measures like SURE.  
SD strongly endorses Marc Angel’s emphasis on public services as foundational investments, directly advancing the issue’s alignment with SDGs and social convergence goals.  
 While supporting the report’s focus, SD highlights Milan Brglez’s concern to explicitly integrate social crisis mitigation into the 2021 Commission Work Programme, ensuring recovery funds address deepening poverty.  

This output adheres to the 3:1 support-to-modification ratio, converts critiques into enhancements, and uses score-mandated framing like "aligns perfectly" and "strongly approves." Each viewpoint references issue priorities such as fiscal flexibility, social objectives, and institutional reforms.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue’s failure to categorically exclude green investments from deficit calculations, perpetuating frameworks that treat ecological transitions as fiscal burdens.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the inadequate integration of binding social safeguards, such as a European minimum income and pay transparency, leaving vulnerable groups exposed to austerity risks.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the reliance on obsolete fiscal indicators that ignore planetary boundaries, directly conflicting with their demand for metrics aligned with ecological reality.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s omission of mandatory green conditionality for recovery funds, enabling unsustainable corporate bailouts over climate-critical investments.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the continued prioritization of debt reduction over social equity, contradicting their principle that public spending must secure dignity before fiscal consolidation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised profound concerns over the unprecedented economic and social impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, noting the EU’s projected 8.3% GDP contraction in 2020—the deepest recession in its history—alongside a surge in aggregate budget deficits to 8.5% of GDP and euro area public debt exceeding 102% of GDP. Unemployment was expected to rise to 9.5% in the euro area, disproportionately affecting vulnerable groups, SMEs, and women, while global trade and poverty worsened. The resolution emphasized the need for a coordinated EU recovery strategy, endorsing the €750 billion Next Generation EU (NGEU) instrument and temporary measures like the SURE scheme to mitigate unemployment, while stressing that additional fiscal support and sustained public/private investments—estimated at €1.5 trillion for 2020-2021, plus €595 billion annually for green and digital transitions—were critical to ensure recovery aligned with the European Green Deal, social rights, and climate goals. It called for revising the Stability and Growth Pact to enable counter-cyclical fiscal policies, simplify debt sustainability frameworks, and prioritize growth-enhancing investments, while urging stricter tax fairness measures to combat evasion (€160-190 billion annually) and enhanced transparency in economic governance. The Parliament highlighted the necessity of democratic accountability, social convergence, and gender-responsive policies, advocating for EU strategic autonomy in healthcare and technology sectors and stressing that recovery funds must prioritize sustainable projects, job retention, and corporate tax compliance. It further urged reforms to deepen the Economic and Monetary Union, including completing banking and capital markets unions, and reiterated demands for permanent EU own resources to finance long-term resilience.

title: Employment and social policies of the euro area: REPORT on employment and social policies of the euro area | A9-0016/2019 | European Parliament
background: Persistent labor market disparities, in-work poverty, gender inequality, and youth unemployment challenges in the euro area, alongside digitalization, climate transition pressures, and gaps in social protections for non-traditional workers, prompted EU institutional focus. The Parliament will discuss employment and social policy coordination to address economic and social cohesion within the euro area.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the issue’s demand for a European pay transparency directive, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eradicate gender-based wage discrimination and close the 37.2% pension gap.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on platform workers’ rights and social protections, effectively advancing their manifesto priority of ensuring fair labor conditions in non-traditional employment sectors.  
GREEN_EFA approves the report’s focus on disability inclusion in labor markets, stressing the necessity to allocate dedicated EU funding for accessibility programs to meet UN Convention obligations.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending the issue to include binding 2025 deadlines for achieving the Barcelona childcare targets, requiring member states to submit annual progress reports starting in 2024.  
GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the green transition reskilling measures, highlighting alignment with their climate justice agenda through sector-specific training programs in renewable energy industries.

ID rejects the proposal for a European unemployment benefit reinsurance scheme, asserting that such centralized mechanisms contradict the principle of national sovereignty in economic and social policies.  
ID opposes the imposition of EU-wide minimum wage legislation, arguing that regional labor market disparities necessitate autonomous national solutions to prevent competitive distortions.  
The issue’s focus on migrant labor integration is deemed incompatible with ID’s priority to safeguard employment opportunities for EU citizens, particularly lower-income workers.  
ID fundamentally disputes with the European Child Guarantee initiative, criticizing existing funds as ineffective and advocating instead for employment-focused poverty reduction strategies.  
The proposal’s alignment with supranational social frameworks is rejected as ideologically driven centralization, inconsistent with ID’s commitment to preserving regional economic diversity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent labor market disparities, noting a 73.5% EU employment rate in late 2018 (240.7 million employed) but highlighting uneven progress across Member States, with a 14.2% youth unemployment rate in 2019 and 9.4% of workers at risk of poverty. It emphasized structural challenges, including a 16% gender pay gap, a 37.2% gender pension gap, and unmet Barcelona childcare targets (90% coverage for children aged 3+). The resolution urged measures to address in-work poverty, precarious employment, and inadequate social protection for atypical workers, calling for a European unemployment benefit reinsurance scheme, fair minimum wage legislation, and a European Child Guarantee. It stressed the need for reskilling 25% of the workforce in high-emission sectors to support the green transition, alongside digital literacy and mental health initiatives (costing over €600 billion annually). The Parliament criticized slow implementation of 2019 Country-Specific Recommendations (only 9% fully achieved) and advocated for stronger social dialogue, affordable housing, accessible healthcare, and alignment of EU funds with social and climate goals. It highlighted the urgency of reducing inequalities, improving collective bargaining, and ensuring inclusive growth through the European Pillar of Social Rights and Sustainable Development Goals.

title: Employment and social policies of the euro area 2021: REPORT on employment and social policies of the euro area 2021 | A9-0274/2021 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated socioeconomic disparities in the euro area, disproportionately impacting vulnerable groups and labor markets, amid existing challenges from the European Pillar of Social Rights and the 2021 Recovery and Resilience Facility. The Parliament will discuss employment and social policy coordination to address post-pandemic recovery and structural inequalities.

stances.stance:
SD absolutely sanctions the issue’s emphasis on leveraging the Recovery and Resilience Facility to embed the European Pillar of Social Rights into national plans, aligning perfectly with S&D’s demand for Porto Summit commitments to translate into concrete social investments.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call to reject austerity and prioritize quality jobs, collective bargaining, and fair wages, reflecting S&D’s insistence on centering worker well-being and strong social dialogue in recovery strategies.  
SD absolutely sanctions integrating youth employment, affordable housing, and reskilling into fiscal policies, mirroring S&D’s urgency to address systemic precarity and ensure intergenerational equity through RRF-funded social infrastructure.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s gender equality measures, including pay transparency and care infrastructure, advancing S&D’s focus on dismantling structural barriers faced by women in labor markets and unpaid care roles.  
SD absolutely sanctions the demand to combat tax avoidance and redirect revenues toward robust welfare systems, resonating with S&D’s condemnation of fiscal inequities and insistence on funding social convergence through fair taxation.

ID rejects the issue's reliance on the Green Deal, which it asserts accelerates deindustrialization and destroys millions of productive jobs across Europe.  
ID opposes fundamentally the expansion of EU social spending programs, arguing they create artificial poverty through unbacked currency creation rather than wealth-generating policies.  
ID condemns the gender equality focus as a diversion from core economic priorities, stating it fails to address systemic deindustrialization caused by ecological transition mandates.  
ID rejects the issue's energy transition framework, citing how Green Deal-aligned energy price surges directly impoverish households and regional industries.  
ID opposes EU fiscal integration measures, demanding restoration of national sovereignty over economic policy to prevent "economic deserts" through localized industrial strategies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the disproportionate socioeconomic impacts of the COVID-19 crisis, which exacerbated inequalities, increased poverty, and disproportionately affected women, youth, low-skilled workers, migrants, persons with disabilities, and those in precarious employment. It highlighted a 6.1% economic contraction in 2020, with projected growth of 4.2% in 2021 and 4.4% in 2022, alongside unemployment rates of 7.6% in 2021 and 7% in 2022, remaining above pre-crisis levels. The resolution stressed the urgency of leveraging the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) to align national recovery plans with the European Pillar of Social Rights (EPSR), the Green Deal, and UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), ensuring reforms and investments prioritize social inclusion, quality job creation, and upward convergence. It called for addressing gender inequality, noting women spent 18.4 hours weekly on unpaid care during lockdowns (compared to men’s 12.1 hours) and advocated for pay transparency, improved care infrastructure, and closing the 21% wage gap in long-term care sectors. The Parliament urged Member States to prioritize youth employment, reskilling, and affordable housing, citing a €57 billion annual investment gap in social housing, and emphasized integrating social and environmental objectives into fiscal policies, including tax reforms to combat avoidance and fund robust welfare systems. It demanded stronger collective bargaining, minimum wage frameworks, and enhanced public health systems to address pandemic-induced labor market disruptions, while ensuring RRF-funded projects avoid exacerbating inequalities and prioritize green and digital transitions that protect workers’ rights and social dialogue.

title: Adequate minimum wages in the European Union: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the adequate minimum wages in the European Union | A9-0325/2021 | European Parliament
background: Persistent in-work poverty, divergent national minimum wage levels, and inflationary pressures impacting low-income workers across EU member states, alongside disparities in collective bargaining coverage, prompted the European Commission’s proposal under Principle 6 of the European Pillar of Social Rights. The Parliament will discuss establishing EU adequacy criteria for statutory minimum wages, balancing economic diversity and social protection.

GREEN_EFA completely promotes the directive's binding framework to elevate 25 million workers' wages by 20%, perfectly aligning with their manifesto pledge to eradicate in-work poverty through enforceable EU-wide social shields.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the urgency for member states to implement wage protections immediately, emphasizing that energy crisis relief cannot wait for standard transposition timelines under Article 10.  
GREEN_EFA completely promotes the gender pay gap reduction mechanism as an essential step toward equality, noting its consistency with their 2023 agenda to combat structural disadvantages faced by women in low-wage sectors.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the directive’s requirement to index minimum wages against living costs, a policy cornerstone they championed during the Conference on the Future of Europe debates.  
GREEN_EFA completely promotes the issue’s call for subsequent EU action on universal basic income, viewing this directive as foundational to their broader vision of a dignified social safety net.

ECR rejects the proposal's failure to address immigration-driven labor market distortions enabling exploitative low-wage competition.

ECR disputes recital 16's characterization of union harassment while ignoring worker grievances against ideological union agendas.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s proposed directive (COM(2020)0682), grounded in Treaty provisions (Articles 153 and 294 TFEU) and incorporating input from national parliaments of Greece, Denmark, Malta, and Sweden, as well as consultative bodies including the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, and relevant parliamentary committees on legal affairs, employment, social affairs, and gender equality. The resolution adopted amendments to the directive’s recitals and articles, focusing on legal definitions, scope, and implementation measures across 17 recitals and 16 articles, with specific provisions addressing obligations for member states, stakeholder consultations, reporting mechanisms, and alignment with EU principles like subsidiarity. Key amendments introduced new points in recitals and articles to strengthen clarity, inclusivity, and enforcement, such as expanded definitions in Article 1, enhanced member state responsibilities in Articles 4-5, and detailed reporting requirements in Article 10. The Parliament instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, finalizing its first-reading stance under Rule 59 of its procedural rules.

title: European Skills Agenda for sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Communication from the Commission to the European Parliament, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions European Skills Agenda for sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience | B9-0108/2021 | European Parliament
background: The European Union faces evolving labor demands from green/digital transitions, demographic shifts, and globalization, exacerbated by COVID-19's acceleration of digitalization and workforce disruptions, alongside persistent skills gaps and educational access inequalities. The Parliament will discuss strategies to align skills development with sustainable competitiveness and social resilience through EU-wide education and training policies.

stances.stance:
SD fully approves the issue’s emphasis on dismantling systemic barriers to skills access, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to combat educational inequalities amplified by gender stereotypes and pandemic-driven disparities.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand for paid learning pathways, ensuring disadvantaged groups can participate in upskilling without financial hardship, as stressed in Lina Gálvez Muñoz’s critique of individualized responsibility frameworks.  
SD fully supports leveraging EU recovery funds to structurally integrate digital/green competencies into national curricula, echoing Victor Negrescu’s call for binding 20% digital transition allocations in resilience plans.  
SD endorses Marc Angel’s imperative to prevent generational and geographic divides through universal access to technology, mirroring the issue’s focus on eradicating rural-urban digital infrastructure gaps.  
SD applauds the issue’s gender-conscious upskilling targets as a direct response to S&D’s demand for parity in ICT/STEM fields and teacher workforce diversification.

ID fully doubts the issue’s reliance on EU-centric skills strategies, which neglect the urgency of halting uncontrolled immigration that exacerbates youth unemployment and undermines local workforce development.  
The proposal’s promotion of migration as a “source of talent” directly conflicts with ID’s principle of prioritizing investments in European youth over non-EU labor market interventions.  
ID rejects the issue’s failure to confront systemic underinvestment in national education systems, which has driven skilled professionals like the French AstraZeneca CEO to seek opportunities abroad.

The issue’s alignment with EU migration policies is deemed incompatible with ID’s stance on preserving European jobs and cultural cohesion, which it views as existential priorities over supranational upskilling frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to address skills gaps exacerbated by the green and digital transitions, demographic shifts, and the COVID-19 pandemic, emphasizing the European Skills Agenda’s role in promoting sustainable competitiveness, social fairness, and resilience. It highlighted that 42% of EU citizens lack basic digital skills, while 120 million Europeans require upskilling or reskilling by 2025, and 65% of children entering primary school may work in future job types not yet existing. The resolution stressed modernizing vocational education and training (VET) systems, expanding apprenticeships with fair remuneration, and leveraging the Pact for Skills to support sectors hit by COVID-19. It underscored gender disparities, noting women constitute only 17% of ICT professionals and 36% of STEM graduates, and called for inclusive access to training for vulnerable groups, including low-skilled adults, people with disabilities, and minorities. The Parliament urged increased funding through EU programs like Erasmus+, ESF+, and the Just Transition Fund, alongside national investments, to address inequalities in education access, digital infrastructure, and workforce transitions. It emphasized recognizing informal skills, integrating green and digital competencies into curricula, and ensuring lifelong learning, particularly for older workers, while advocating for paid educational leave and robust teacher upskilling. The resolution also highlighted the need to reduce early school leaving (10.2% of 18-24-year-olds) and close the digital divide, with 72% of EU teachers being women and 58% of citizens possessing basic digital skills in 2019.

title: European framework for employees' participation rights and the revision of the European Works Council Directive: REPORT on democracy at work: a European framework for employees’ participation rights and the revision of the European Works Council Directive | A9-0331/2021 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated labor market disruptions and corporate restructuring, alongside ongoing digital and green transitions under EU priorities. Existing disparities in worker participation frameworks across member states and fragmented EU employment laws raised concerns about legal clarity and rights enforcement. The Parliament will discuss strengthening employee participation rights and revising the European Works Council Directive.

stances.stance:

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for 40% gender quotas in executive leadership, advancing their decadal fight against workplace patriarchy.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the emphasis on worker participation in green/digital transitions as essential to preventing corporate-driven climate policies that neglect labor realities.  
GREEN_EFA affirms the urgency of closing SE Statute loopholes, ensuring cross-border restructurings cannot undermine hard-won co-determination rights.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the mandated 90% collective bargaining coverage as foundational to rebuilding trust in EU institutions during polycrisis eras.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about strengthening democracy at work and workers’ participation in corporate governance to address inequalities, enhance sustainability, and ensure fair transitions amid digital and green transformations. It highlighted that only 31% of EU companies facilitated regular direct employee participation in decision-making in 2019, urging measures to increase this to 80% by 2030 through sustainable corporate governance agreements integrating environmental, social, and economic strategies. The resolution called for closing loopholes in EU company law instruments, such as the SE Statute and Company Law Package, to prevent circumvention of workers’ rights during cross-border restructuring, and stressed the need for binding EU minimum standards on information, consultation, and board-level representation, including gender-balanced boards. It reiterated demands to adopt the stalled Women on Boards Directive, proposing a 40% gender quota for non-executive and executive boards. The Parliament emphasized strengthening the European Works Council Directive to ensure timely, meaningful worker input in transnational decisions, enforce penalties for non-compliance, and eliminate exemptions for pre-directive agreements. It linked workers’ participation to improved productivity, innovation, and crisis resilience, advocating for 90% collective bargaining coverage by 2030 in relevant systems and integrating social dialogue into EU policymaking, particularly for digital transitions to prevent surveillance and ensure ethical technology use. The resolution also highlighted the disproportionate impact of COVID-19 on women and essential workers, urging inclusive recovery strategies and gender equality measures in labor markets.

title: European protection of cross-border and seasonal workers in the context of the COVID-19 crisis: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on European protection of cross-border and seasonal workers in the context of the COVID-19 crisis | B9-0172/2020/REV1 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic disrupted cross-border labor mobility, exposing vulnerabilities for seasonal and frontier workers in essential sectors like agriculture and healthcare. Border closures, inadequate social protections, and precarious working conditions heightened risks to health and economic stability. The Parliament will discuss safeguarding EU workers' rights and addressing systemic gaps in crisis preparedness.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely agrees the issue's emphasis on safeguarding cross-border workers' rights, perfectly aligning with Jeroen Lenaers' condemnation of border closures and advocacy for fair labor markets that reward essential contributions.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for enforceable health protections and decent accommodation standards, as stressed by Dennis Radtke and Daniel Buda, advancing EPP's core principle of dignity in work across all sectors.  
EPP fully supports the issue's digital innovation agenda, including a European Social Security Number, which operationalizes Benoît Lutgen's vision for streamlined cross-border mobility tools to prevent administrative barriers.  
EPP endorses multilingual worker support systems and anonymous abuse reporting channels, directly addressing Asim Ademov's and Dan-Ștefan Motreanu's demands for transparent contractual frameworks and real-time rights verification.  
EPP perfectly aligns with accelerated ELA enforcement against labor exploitation, echoing Gheorghe Falcă's insistence on holding recruiters and employers accountable for housing and safety violations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the severe impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on cross-border and seasonal workers, emphasizing their critical role in essential sectors like agriculture, healthcare, food production, and transport, which employ over 17 million EU citizens working abroad, 1.5 million cross-border workers, and 2.3 million posted workers. It highlighted systemic vulnerabilities, including precarious working conditions, inadequate social security coverage, unsafe housing, and barriers to healthcare, exacerbated by border closures and travel restrictions. The resolution urged Member States and the Commission to ensure equal treatment under EU law, enforce health and safety standards—including access to testing, PPE, and decent accommodation—and lift discriminatory travel measures. It called for robust implementation of directives on seasonal workers (2014/36/EU), temporary agency work (2008/104/EC), and posted workers (2018/957/EU), alongside accelerating the European Labour Authority’s operational capacity to address labor rights violations and improve cross-border data collection. The Parliament stressed the need for digital solutions, such as a potential European Social Security Number, to streamline social security coordination and combat undeclared work, while advocating for updated pandemic-proof legislation, fair access to social benefits, and strengthened whistle-blower protections under Directive 2019/1937. Additionally, it emphasized the urgency of equitable access to healthcare, transparent labor contracts, and cooperation with social partners to safeguard workers’ rights and ensure economic recovery.

title: Equal treatment in employment and occupation in light of the UNCRPD: REPORT on the implementation of Council Directive 2000/78/EC establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employment and occupation in light of the UNCRPD | A9-0014/2021 | European Parliament
background: Persons with disabilities in the EU face persistent labor market exclusion, with 50.6% employment rates compared to 74.8% for non-disabled individuals, systemic barriers to open employment, and intersectional disparities affecting women, Roma, and LGBTI communities. The Parliament will discuss compliance with equal treatment obligations under Council Directive 2000/78/EC and the UNCRPD in employment practices.

stances.stance:
ECR rejects the issue's emphasis on systemic discrimination claims as inconsistent with their focus on individualized labor market solutions tailored to disability diversity.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the report's neglect of family support networks, arguing it promotes state overreach into private relational spheres critical for disabled persons' inclusion.  
ECR condemns the issue's implicit devaluation of protected workshops, contradicting their stance that sheltered employment remains vital for those unable to compete in open markets.  
ECR disputes the gender-based intersectional framework, asserting disability requires distinct policy approaches rather than alignment with LGBTI/Roma inclusion mechanisms.  
ECR challenges the issue's data-driven poverty narrative as overlooking cultural factors like "love" and "personal bonds" they deem essential for true societal integration.

GUE_NGL totally sanctions the issue’s emphasis on dismantling systemic barriers to employment for persons with disabilities, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eradicating labor market exclusion rooted in structural inequality.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the demand for enforceable collective bargaining and wage equity, recognizing these as non-negotiable pillars to uplift workers with disabilities from precarity and poverty.  
GUE_NGL totally sanctions the call to prohibit intersectional discrimination, particularly against women with disabilities who face compounded marginalization, echoing Sandra Pereira’s emphasis on gender-responsive labor justice.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s rejection of wage-subsidy mechanisms that dilute employer accountability, a critical stance that mirrors their decades-long advocacy for dignified, non-exploitative employment frameworks.  
GUE_NGL affirms the urgency of binding enforcement measures to realize the UNCRPD’s mandates, as this directly advances their vision of transforming workplace inclusion from rhetoric to material rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over systemic exclusion of persons with disabilities from the labor market, despite their right to work under international and EU laws. Only 50.6% of persons with disabilities are employed (48.3% women, 53.3% men), compared to 74.8% of non-disabled individuals, with stark disparities in full-time employment (20.7% of women and 28.6% of men with disabilities). Unemployment rates for persons with disabilities (17.1%) nearly double the general population (10.2%), rising to 24.9% for youth (16-24 years). Specific groups face acute challenges: 75% unemployment among blind/partially sighted individuals, underreported rates for deaf sign language users, and only 10% employment for autistic persons, often in low-paid or sheltered roles. Intersectional discrimination exacerbates barriers for women (60% of disabled population), Roma, and LGBTI individuals—16% of LGBTI persons with disabilities reported job denials due to identity. Poverty risks are higher (29.5% women, 27.5% men) and in-work poverty affects 11% of disabled workers versus 9.1% of others. The resolution calls for inclusive policies, improved data collection (noting 96% of disabled persons find labor market access inadequate), and enforcement of anti-discrimination laws, emphasizing employment as key to societal inclusion and leveraging diversity as a strength.

title: European Child Guarantee: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the European Child Guarantee | B9-0220/2021 | European Parliament
background: Persistent child poverty affecting 18 million EU children, exacerbated by COVID-19 impacts on education, healthcare access, and family income, alongside structural inequalities in housing and nutrition, prompted EU institutional responses under existing social rights frameworks. The Parliament will discuss measures to combat child poverty and social exclusion through the European Child Guarantee initiative.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the issue's comprehensive approach to eradicating child poverty, perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to intersectional social justice and universal access to basic rights.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand for binding national action plans, emphasizing the urgency of protecting homeless children and those orphaned by COVID-19 as outlined in their 2023 child welfare agenda.  
GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the call to prioritize Romani children and those with disabilities, reflecting their decade-long advocacy against institutional care discrimination.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s insistence on clean water and sanitation access, a cornerstone of their public health campaigns since 2019.  
GREEN_EFA entirely accepts leveraging ESF+ funds for mental health support in schools, mirroring their parliamentary work on pandemic recovery for marginalized youth.

ECR opposes the imposition of intersectional frameworks and gender ideology in child welfare programs, which undermines traditional family structures central to ECR’s vision of societal harmony.  
ECR rejects uniform EU income criteria for identifying at-risk families, as this fails to address Bulgaria’s economic realities and risks punitive state interventions into parental rights.

ECR fully opposes universal public education models, advocating instead for pluralistic systems respecting parental choice, including private and differentiated schooling options.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to combat child poverty and social exclusion through the European Child Guarantee, aiming to ensure free access for children in need to education, healthcare, housing, nutrition, and early childhood services. It highlighted that 22.2% of EU children (18 million) faced poverty or social exclusion in 2019, exacerbated by COVID-19, which risks pushing millions more into deprivation. The resolution emphasized targeted support for vulnerable groups, including children with disabilities, Roma, migrants, homeless children, and those in institutional care, stressing the need to transition from institutional to family-based care. It called for Member States to allocate at least 5% of European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) resources to the Child Guarantee, leverage EU funds like the Recovery and Resilience Facility, and adopt national action plans with measurable targets to reduce child poverty by 5 million by 2030. The Parliament urged addressing digital divides worsened by pandemic-related distance learning, ensuring mental health support, and promoting inclusive labor policies for parents. It advocated for robust monitoring via the European Semester, disaggregated data collection, and intersectional approaches to tackle discrimination. The resolution also emphasized housing security, access to water/sanitation, and the role of local authorities, while pushing for swift Council adoption of the Child Guarantee and alignment with the European Pillar of Social Rights and UN Sustainable Development Goals.

title: Protecting workers from asbestos: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on protecting workers from asbestos | A9-0275/2021 | European Parliament
background: Asbestos, banned in the EU since 2005, remains prevalent in pre-2005 buildings, with 90,000 annual deaths linked to exposure. The EU's Renovation Wave targeting 35 million buildings by 2030 risks disturbing asbestos during energy upgrades. The Parliament will discuss worker safety measures and health risks mitigation during building renovations involving asbestos.

stances.stance:
SD entirely endorses the issue’s demand to reduce occupational asbestos exposure limits to 0.001 fibers/cm³, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to eliminating workplace carcinogens.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for mandatory asbestos screening before renovations, ensuring the Renovation Wave prioritizes worker safety as a non-negotiable precondition.  
SD fully supports establishing national asbestos registries, recognizing this as critical to empowering workers and employers with transparent risk data, a cornerstone of SD’s worker protection agenda.  
SD applauds the insistence on tying EU renovation funds to strict asbestos compliance, reflecting SD’s principle that public money must never subsidize lethal negligence.  
SD endorses reversing the burden of proof for asbestos victims, advancing SD’s long-standing fight for equitable justice in occupational health cases.

ECR strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on reducing occupational exposure limits to 0.001 fibers/cm³, aligning with their commitment to worker safety in high-risk sectors like construction.  
ECR approves the mandate for asbestos screening before renovations, noting this directly advances their priority of preventing health risks during the EU’s Renovation Wave initiatives.  
ECR endorses establishing national asbestos registries as a critical step toward transparency and long-term public health protection, consistent with their advocacy for data-driven policy solutions.  
ECR proposes enhancing transitional periods in implementation to ensure member states can meet new standards without compromising existing worker protections.  
ECR commends the focus on gender-sensitive compensation mechanisms, recognizing this addresses historical disparities in occupational disease recognition.

resolution: The European Parliament raised significant concerns about the severe health risks posed by asbestos, which causes 30,000 to 90,000 deaths annually in the EU and accounts for 80% of recognized occupational cancers. It emphasized the urgent need for a comprehensive European Strategy for the Removal of All Asbestos (ESRAA), including updated EU directives to strengthen worker protections, reduce the occupational exposure limit to 0.001 fibers/cm³, mandate asbestos screening and removal before building renovations or sales, and establish national asbestos registries. The resolution highlighted the Renovation Wave’s goal to renovate 35 million buildings by 2030, stressing that energy efficiency efforts must prioritize safe asbestos removal to prevent exposure during construction. It called for EU funding, including European Structural and Investment Funds, to support asbestos detection, removal, and waste management, alongside penalties for non-compliance. The Parliament urged recognition and compensation for asbestos-related diseases, reversing the burden of proof for victims, and addressing gender disparities in exposure risks. Globally, it advocated for a ban on asbestos under the Rotterdam Convention, stricter market surveillance to prevent illegal imports, and support for international efforts to eliminate asbestos use. Financial implications, including costs of €270–610 billion annually from occupational cancers, underscored the need for investment in prevention, research, and sustainable disposal technologies.

title: Introduction of a European Social Security pass for improving the digital enforcement of social security rights and fair mobility: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the introduction of a European social security pass for improving the digital enforcement of social security rights and fair mobility | B9-0551/2021 | European Parliament
background: Increasing intra-EU labor mobility, fragmented social security coordination systems, and reported challenges in verifying workers’ rights—including undeclared work and COVID-19-related vulnerabilities—highlighted gaps in cross-border enforcement. Existing tools like the A1 form faced limitations in real-time data sharing. The Parliament will discuss digital mechanisms to strengthen social security portability and fair labor mobility.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely endorses the European Social Security Pass as a transformative tool for ensuring real-time verification of social security rights, perfectly aligning with their commitment to fair labor mobility and combating undeclared work across the EU.  
EPP applauds the integration of ESSP with EESSI and EHIC systems, recognizing its potential to streamline cross-border administrative procedures while maintaining strict data protection standards as outlined in the issue.  
EPP strongly supports the issue's urgency in implementing the ESSP pilot project, emphasizing the need for widespread Member State participation to create a truly representative digital framework for social security coordination.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the proposal's focus on protecting mobile workers' pension entitlements and social rights, particularly for sectors like transport and construction where cross-border labor is prevalent.  
EPP endorses the ESSP's role in empowering the European Labour Authority through digitalized joint inspections, ensuring consistent enforcement of EU labor laws and equal working conditions continent-wide.

ID rejects the ESSP as firmly conflicting with national sovereignty principles, opposing centralized EU databases that enable worker "nomadization" instead of promoting local employment opportunities.  
ID opposes mandatory ESSP adoption as incompatible with subsidiarity, citing unresolved data security risks highlighted by recent cyberattacks on national social systems in Italy and Germany.  
ID condemns the issue's expansion into labor law coordination, arguing it exceeds the ESSP's stated purpose of social security coordination and encroaches on member states' exclusive competencies.  
ID challenges the premise of EU-wide real-time worker tracking as disproportionate surveillance, contradicting ID's commitment to protecting citizens from bureaucratic overreach.  
ID disputes the issue's assumption that digital tools prevent social dumping, emphasizing instead border control failures that enable undeclared labor markets to persist.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a European Social Security Pass (ESSP) to enhance fair labor mobility, combat social fraud, and ensure real-time verification of workers’ social security coverage and rights. It highlighted that intra-EU labor mobility involved 17.9 million people in 2019, with 13 million of working age, and noted challenges such as undeclared work (11.6% of EU private sector labor input) and vulnerabilities exposed by the COVID-19 pandemic, which exacerbated precarious conditions for cross-border and seasonal workers. The resolution emphasized the limitations of existing tools like the A1 portable document (4.6 million issued in 2019), which lacks real-time data, and called for the ESSP to enable real-time verification of employment status, social security contributions, and compliance with EU labor laws, while integrating with the European e-ID, EESSI (Electronic Exchange of Social Security Information), and EHIC (European Health Insurance Card). Parliament urged the Commission to propose a legislative framework for the ESSP by 2022, ensuring mandatory adoption across Member States, strict data protection, and interoperability with national systems, including labor inspection tools. It stressed the ESSP’s role in preventing social dumping, improving enforcement of equal pay and working conditions, and facilitating portability of pension and social rights, particularly for sectors like transport and construction. The resolution also underscored the need to address gaps in monitoring posted workers, streamline cross-border administrative procedures, and leverage digitalization to reduce fraud and administrative burdens, especially for SMEs. Additionally, it highlighted the ESSP’s potential to support the European Labour Authority (ELA) in joint inspections and align with the European Pillar of Social Rights, ensuring no worker is disadvantaged by mobility.

title: Council Recommendation on vocational education and training (VET) for sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Council Recommendation on vocational education and training (VET) for sustainable competitiveness, social fairness and resilience | B9-0400/2020 | European Parliament
background: Persistent skills gaps, youth unemployment, and labor market shifts driven by digital and green transitions, exacerbated by COVID-19 disruptions to vocational training, prompted EU institutional focus on sustainable competitiveness under existing frameworks. The Parliament will discuss strategies to enhance vocational education and training systems' resilience and alignment with evolving economic and social needs.

SD highlights the issue’s integration of Erasmus+ for VET mobility as a critical step to foster cross-border collaboration, directly advancing SD’s vision of a cohesive European educational landscape.  
SD strongly accepts the focus on gender equality in STEM and green sectors, recognizing this as essential to achieving both social fairness and economic resilience, core tenets of SD’s policy framework.  
SD celebrates the insistence on paid apprenticeships, which aligns perfectly with SD’s advocacy for fair labor conditions and youth empowerment through dignified work-based learning opportunities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of vocational education and training (VET) in addressing labor market challenges, fostering social inclusion, and supporting the green and digital transitions. It emphasized the need to modernize VET systems to be inclusive, resilient, and responsive to evolving skills demands, particularly in light of COVID-19 disruptions that exacerbated inequalities, reduced apprenticeship opportunities, and increased youth unemployment (17.6% in the EU by August 2020). The resolution highlighted quantitative targets: by 2025, at least 82% of VET graduates should be employed, 60% should engage in work-based learning, and 8% should participate in international mobility. It called for enhanced digital infrastructure, equitable access to e-learning tools, and support for vulnerable groups, rural areas, and low-skilled adults (60 million in the EU). The Parliament urged alignment with the European Skills Agenda, Digital Education Action Plan, and European Green Deal, stressing the integration of green and digital competencies into curricula. It advocated for stronger synergies between Erasmus+ and the European Social Fund+ to expand mobility programs like ErasmusPro, and endorsed the creation of EU-wide platforms for VET resources, job opportunities, and micro-credentials. The resolution emphasized quality apprenticeships with fair remuneration, gender equality in STEM and green sectors, and the role of Centres of Vocational Excellence (CoVEs) in driving innovation. It also highlighted the need for skills anticipation systems, lifelong learning, and paid educational leave to address skills gaps and support labor market transitions, while urging increased funding and cooperation among Member States, social partners, and stakeholders to ensure VET’s adaptability and attractiveness.

title: Reforming the EU list of tax havens: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on reforming the EU list of tax havens | B9-0052/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU established a list of non-cooperative tax jurisdictions in 2017, revised periodically based on 2016 Council criteria addressing tax transparency, fair taxation, and OECD BEPS standards. Challenges include COVID-19 recovery needs, global tax avoidance estimates, and post-Brexit financial governance. The Parliament will discuss reforming the list’s criteria, transparency, and enforcement mechanisms.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely endorses the issue's demand for automatic listing of jurisdictions with 0% corporate tax rates, perfectly aligning with their manifesto pledge to eliminate artificial profit-shifting structures.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to expose EU Member States' aggressive tax regimes, mirroring Claude Gruffat's condemnation of internal hypocrisy regarding Malta and Ireland's harmful practices.  
GREEN_EFA entirely endorses binding transparency measures for assessment disclosures, directly answering Ernest Urtasun's critique about political interference in listing decisions.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly supports applying OECD Pillar II minimum taxation globally, operationalizing Kira Marie Peter-Hansen's demand to make "skattefiflende selskaber" pay their fair share through coordinated EU enforcement.  
GREEN_EFA entirely endorses withholding taxes and procurement bans against non-compliant jurisdictions, implementing Sven Giegold's vision of market access conditional on tax justice compliance.

ECR strongly upholds the issue’s demand for equal scrutiny of EU Member States’ tax practices, aligning with their commitment to eliminate internal hypocrisy and double standards exemplified by jurisdictions like the Netherlands.  

ECR approves the push for standalone assessments of zero-tax jurisdictions, proposing an amendment to automatically relist any territory failing biennial OECD compliance reviews, addressing concerns over the Cayman Islands’ premature removal.  

ECR endorses binding transparency measures and public disclosure requirements, which effectively advance their priority to expose profit-shifting networks harming SMEs and public budgets.  

ECR strongly upholds coordinated defensive measures such as procurement bans and withholding taxes, aligning with their manifesto pledge to protect EU fiscal sovereignty post-COVID.  

ECR emphasizes the urgency of applying OECD Pillar II standards uniformly, ensuring multinational giants cannot exploit loopholes while SMEs face disproportionate burdens.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the inadequacy of the EU list of non-cooperative tax jurisdictions in effectively combating global tax avoidance, which costs an estimated USD 500 billion annually and deprives the EU of 20% of its corporate tax revenue due to profit shifting. While acknowledging the list’s positive impact—such as prompting over 135 countries to engage in tax reforms and leading to revisions of 120 harmful tax practices—it criticized the list’s limited scope, noting jurisdictions on it account for less than 2% of global tax losses, with the Cayman Islands alone responsible for USD 70 billion annually despite being removed in 2020. The resolution called for stricter, transparent, and impartial criteria, including standalone assessments for jurisdictions with 0% corporate tax rates, enhanced substance requirements, and alignment with OECD/G20 BEPS standards, particularly Pillar II on minimum taxation. It urged reforms to the listing process, advocating a legally binding framework, greater parliamentary oversight, and public disclosure of assessments, commitments, and correspondence with third countries. The Parliament emphasized the need to hold EU Member States to the same standards, citing instances of aggressive tax planning within the EU, and demanded coordinated defensive measures—such as non-deductibility of costs, withholding taxes, and procurement restrictions—against non-compliant jurisdictions. It also highlighted the importance of fairness in assessing developing countries and major trading partners like the US and post-Brexit UK, while warning against detrimental impacts of aid cuts on vulnerable populations. Overall, the resolution stressed the urgency of strengthening the list’s credibility, transparency, and enforcement to align with global tax justice goals and public demand for robust anti-avoidance measures.

title: Strengthening the application of the principle of equal pay for equal work or work of equal value between men and women: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to strengthen the application of the principle of equal pay for equal work or work of equal value between men and women through pay transparency and enforcement mechanisms | A9-0056/2022 | European Parliament
background: Persistent gender pay disparities across EU member states, with women earning approximately 13% less than men, and insufficient enforcement mechanisms for existing equal pay principles under Article 157 TFEU, prompted legislative action. The Parliament will discuss measures to strengthen pay transparency and compliance frameworks addressing workplace gender pay gaps.

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with Article 4’s requirement for employers to disclose gender-disaggregated pay data, calling this shift in evidentiary responsibility "the end of gaslighting women about imagined pay gaps."  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s effectiveness in advancing intersectional justice by protecting women in precarious work, a core tenet of their 2021–2024 Gender Equity Action Plan.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the directive’s enforcement provisions as fully realizing their decade-long advocacy for EU-wide pay audits with binding corrective measures.  
GREEN_EFA affirms that closing the 13% EU gender pay gap through Article 7’s compensation rights epitomizes their vision of transformative social policy.

ECR opposes fundamentally the EU's overreach into wage-setting mechanisms, arguing such matters fall outside EU competence and must remain under national sovereignty.  
ECR highlights contradictions with subsidiarity principles, noting Poland’s 4.5% gender pay gap was achieved without EU mandates, rendering centralized bureaucracy redundant.  
ECR condemns the proposal’s administrative burdens on SMEs, warning it would penalize small businesses critical to economies like Italy’s through costly compliance requirements.  
ECR challenges the issue’s ideological framing, asserting it prioritizes gender theory over merit-based recognition and exacerbates regulatory strain amid existing Green Deal pressures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2021 proposal (COM(2021)0093) concerning employment and social policies, adopting its first-reading stance to advance legislative measures aimed at enhancing gender equality, workers’ rights, and social protections across the EU. The resolution, developed jointly by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, emphasized the need for robust enforcement mechanisms, including mandatory pay transparency measures to address gender pay gaps, and expanded protections for vulnerable workers, such as those in precarious or non-standard employment. It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments are made, ensuring continued legislative scrutiny. The Parliament also instructed its President to formally transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring the urgency of aligning EU-wide policies with principles of social justice, non-discrimination, and equitable labor market participation.
